fua4N0_RC9z5Jj1bfA6QOQ.text: If you love the other tasty parts of the animal, this is where it all began.  A true landmark. Have been eating here just shy of 16 years. Popularity (you can thank that meathead Anthony B.) and Michelin ratings have made this place a tad too crowded.  Still, the oxtail marrow is wonderful, as well as the jowel of the pig.  Deep, rich meaty flavors.  The seafood is also delightful.  I once had beautiful oysters from France.  Beware: the sea urchin was mushy; not the quality of the ones from Santa Barbara, CA.

7gVCxObP_Q3ZjB-sSXqMkQ.text: It's been over a year since I last ate here, so my memory's pretty foggy. However, I do recall that while their bone marrow on toast was pretty tasty, I don't remember any other dish being singularly spectacular.The restaurant itself is kind of small and quite, quite busy. I don't think I'd come back if I'm ever back in London... :/

N9sf5LBVeEksPFqrkpvbjQ.text: The marrow salad was good, but I went in not knowing it was a big deal so you might temper your expectations. Our staff didn't have much insight when it came to wine selection. Desert was OK. The Roast Middlewhite I ordered was tender, but not particularly flavorful. The atmosphere was extremely pleasing. I'd have to go back before I bump them down to three stars. Oh, the waiter drowned a member of our party in Champagne, apologized and then about 15 individuals came by to say that the Champagne was on the house. Duh, unimpressed.

t3WGfRjn6PfjFpqe6G2OgQ.text: We were meeting some friends who were running late - of course, since we didn't have working cell phones, we had no way of knowing HOW late, or even whether they'd get there in time for us to be seated before they closed. The bartender was very helpful, from recommending a delicious beverage (cidre breton. How I wish I could get it in Pittsburgh.) to letting me use the house phone to call their other location to see if our friends had ended up there.As soon as I dialed the other location, our friends walked in. Fantastic! Now we can eat. Do you know how hard it is to pick a meal on a menu that includes venison liver, mallard, braised rabbit and ox cheeks? We started with the bone marrow appetizer. I'd never had bone marrow, but it was everything Anthony Bourdain had led me to expect. Rich, buttery, flavorful (although the flavor was subtle). Then I decided to order the rabbit and my husband the ox cheeks - but the ox cheeks were sold out, so he got the rabbit and I got the venison liver. Good decision - I didn't love the rabbit (there's something about the texture that I don't like), but the venison was sublime. If you like venison, which I do. Our friends ordered the mallard (loved the wing, was less impressed with the breast) and the quail (glad he tried it, but didn't enjoy the flavor). And then, of course, we had to try desert: My husband and I shared the apple crumble with custard, which I thought was the best thing I'd ever eaten in my life until I tried a bite of my friend's lemon posset, which was even better.Great service, great food. Expensive, yes, but not out of line with the quality and the experience. So glad we decided to give it a shot!

wwYxxSeeUukcJCZJIuHN1A.text: I've been wanting to go to St John for years. I must say, it didn't disappoint. Every aspect of my experience was phenomenal. From the design (interior, wine label, menu, Twitter account, website, etc etc etc) to the food itself, everything here clearly has the level of attention any excellent experience requires.We started at the bar, where i didn't have the opportunity to try the variety of different beers available because i felt obliged (in a good way) to try the restaurants own wine. After trying it (extensively) i can confirm that it does indeed work. It tastes good too.I opted for the bone marrow as a starter (which was wind-blowingly good) and went for the pigeon for my main course. I ended with an espresso.A note about the pigeon: while i wasn't such a huge fan of the bird/meat I thoroughly enjoyed eating something so perfectly prepared. Also, i was rather surprised to discover just how much meat a pigeon actually offers. I would not recommend pigeon for unadventurous eaters. If however you appreciate food for all it's qualities (how it's prepared, cooked and to experience a new flavour) I would strongly recommend it.While my experience was fantastic, to do things right one needs to reserve an entire suckling pig a week in advance and bring 10 friends, for this is what St John are really known for. I've given St John 5 stars based on it's entire experience, not simply it's food VS price ratio. Follow them on Twitter @SJRestaurant

GmVoieme5sC3MGojxXOD5A.text: I had an amazing meal here with 2 friends. The bone marrow lived up to all the hype and the meal was one of the best I've ever had. We had fried skate cheeks that were tender and pillowy. I had calves livers and my friend had pigeon. The menu changes, but we were very satisfied with the presentation and simplicity of the cooking.The bread pudding was sublime. A must try.

z2LcuY7aUSoAvhXLiLmYNQ.text: St John Restaurant is supposedly one of the best restaurants of London if not England, but I was not impressed with the food. It wasn't bad but it just did not live up to its name and hype. The bone marrow wasn't all that special and it was quite a bit of work to scoop out the marrow. I had a similar dish in Paris that was better, in taste and mechanics. My lamb entree was cold and taste-less. Maybe I ordered wrong or perhaps it was having an off-day. The hot chocolate pudding, however, is one of the best desserts I have ever had.

ozd6VTesZlTWMjWm-P14kQ.text: St. John Restaurant is rated #14 on the world restaurant ranking. I really wanted to try it. As I'm here in London and The Fat Duck is fully booked for the next 2 months, I decided on second best and I found my way there tonight.Entering, I was greeted by a traditional, almost working-class ambiance. White walls wilth pegs on the walls all around the room to hang coats. Painted floors, paper table cloths on serviceable furniture. Common silverware. No bread plates. OK. This wasn't about the ambiance. I was greeted by the fellow running the place. Seated immediately, he returned in a few minutes to take my order. The menu was very "English" meaning lots of offal, eel, and the types of fish preparations we don't often see in the US.I began with a glass of NV St John Brut Rose. It wasn't bad. Nice fruit, good nose. For my appetizer I went with the Hake & Monk's Beard. I'd never had Monk's Beard, a vegetable grown on northern European coastal lands. It looks a bit like fettucini but green. The hake came served in flakes and chunks. Both were tossed in a bit of lemon with capers. Unfortunately I didn't realize the dish was served cold. I'm not big on cold fish but I braved it. The dish had little flavor and the flavor of the fish was more to the nose than the tongue. I didn't care for it.For my entree I decided on Beef Mince & Tatties. A traditional Scottish dish, Mince is minced beef with spices and tatties are simply boiled potatoes. A side of greens was a dish of outer cabbage leaves lightly cooked. The greens were done perfectly. The beef was fine and boiled potatoes...well, they're boiled potatoes. The dish had very little real flavor. This seemed to be the theme for the dinner...a lack of real flavors. A glass of Cotes du Rhone Villages (2007) accompanied the entree course. The wine was fine.My waitress brought my food, picked up my plates and asked me what I wanted. Perfunctory. No personality...just like the food and ambiance.Dessert was the Apple Pie & Custard and it was the highlight of the night. Heavy sweet crust certainly outweighed the apples but still it offered flavor. Espresso and done.What a disappointment. I can't believe the ranking, the Michelin star or the reviews on Yelp. This is simply mediocre stuff.

ng94j5myd0ECv-TtrKXxRQ.text: This restaurant has a very unique feel to it. Since Anthony Bourdain said Fergus Henderson's bone marrow and parsley salad was the last thing he would eat if he was on death row made me curious and to try it. So we ordered it and it was good, but I've had better. However, Fegus is the one who started the whole movement on eating from head to toe parts of animals, so other chefs could have changed this classic dish. We also ordered the crispy pig skin with water cress salad and I never had anything like it. I'm not a big fan of pigs skin and water cress, but the dressing, the way he toasted the skin made this dish so delicious and I was surprised how much I liked it. I've had water cress cooked before and never ate it raw, but my god, it was appetizing. We also ordered the brown crab on toast and all it is roe mixed with crab meat which gave it that creamy, buttery taste and it went excellent with the toast.  The apple crumble was scrumptious. Came right out of the oven, scorching hot with creme on the side, which made the dessert more like a bread pudding. So delicious, but the menu has other things that they are more famous for, but i was craving for an apple crumble. I had a great dining experience and I'd definitely come back. What made the experience even better was seeing Fergus actually there, so we bought his book and had him sign it. Extremely talented man and very nice.

BXfEjyJ1EsYAvs4BS7HQ4w.text: If you are looking for the quintessential British meal, your search ends now.I very much enjoyed my meal at St John Bread and Wine in Spitalfields a couple years ago, so I was looking forward to dining at the proper restaurant location in Farringdon. We booked a reservation at St John for my boyfriend's birthday, as he always wanted to dine at St John and we all wanted to try it out as well. When we arrived at the restaurant, we waited for a brief moment at the bar and enjoyed a bottle of the house white, which I HIGHLY recommend, especially for the summer. Close to the bar downstairs is also the bakery and a small seating area, which was quite quaint and lovely. As we finally took our seats, I immediately noticed all of the exotic meats on the menu, none which I had ever seen someone consume. The majority of our party all agreed that they wanted the bone marrow (the restaurant's speciality). The whole table agreed that it was absolutely delicious. My boyfriend also ordered the pigeon, which he found very unique but tasty as well. As a vegetarian, I stuck to the simple rocket salad and a few of the side orders. The desert menu was absolutely DIVINE. As a table, we wanted to try everything, so we each ordered a different desert. I must recommend the chocolate pot for all you choco-lovers out there. Simply it is dark chocolate melted into a tiny little pot, which looks quite small when it arrives, However, do not be deceived! It is EXTREMELY rich (but so delicious). A complete must.Overall, for the dining experience, service, and quality of food, I was shocked at the reasonable prices. I will be back very soon!

REDjerlwEHxf_RXJfrbzkw.text: Honestly, the food in general was good but not amazing. This place gets 4 stars because of the Madeleines... I dream of those Madeleines.

oiUTFLN8DrekZNWGibV6xg.text: The restaurant is both amazing and quite pricey. The bar, however, is amazing and totally reasonable. You can come in here at lunchtime and order the best sandwich of your life (or the bone marrow, if you're so inclined - it is delicious) and a pint of Meantime and leave with change from a tenner. Seriously, do it.

yJndOomHme52OiZMYZAOaw.text: great restaurant, solid delivery, fantastic space. have the madeleines or the donuts filled with custard or jam.

YjhfFpJ94ogPAMbD8U_aFQ.text: This place should be a mandatory visit for all Italian and French tourists snootily landing in the capital thinking that it's a beautiful city where people eat crappy food. The fact that a restaurant like this exists, and it's wildly successful, is a great proof not only of the quality and variety of the offer in the city, but also of the maturity in the taste of the London gourmets.I hesitate in describing this as "british" cuisine. In fact, it's a temple of meat, where most of the dishes are cooked with the simplicity and efficacy of home-made Italian food. More than one dish I tasted there reminded me of something that my mother cooks regularly, or that my grandmother used to cook: insofar that I was tempted to go to the kitchen and suggest some creative use of beef lungs or kidneys.The main source of this similarity comes from the fact that most of the dishes at the Sain't John are prepared with less valuable cuts of meat, from what skilful hands extract unexpected (and potentially unfamiliar) tastes through masterful cooking and simple matchings. There are no intrusive sauces trying to cover the taste of the meat: most of the courses are presented in their utter simplicity, and for a real meat lover this is the perfect way to do it.I ordered the ox heart: I love ox heart, my mother used to do that often with parsley and wine. This was just as good. I briefly tasted the beetroot and horseradish that came on the side, but for me (while tasty) they were redundant. I had the opportunity to taste the famous bone marrow (and don't get me started with how bone marrow is central to the Milanese cuisine both for the "ossobuco con polenta" and the properly done "risotto alla milanese") and found it delicious, but it's the chitterlings that I found really amazing, reminding me of tastes that I experienced in my life on a few happy occasions, particularly in some wonderful restaurants in Rome. We picked a random wine from the very good list and it turned out to be a perfect matching. Prices very, very good for this kind of quality, surely helped by the minimalist fittings and the somewhat hasty attitude of the waiters. Even the coffee was good, what could I ask more?

aTvuYW5dZNuAw3iURj4G7g.text: When I first came to London I always wanted to go to this place.  Anthony Bourdain covered it in No Reservations for the London episode.  I thought to myself wow this place must be good.  Their one specialty is the roasted bone marrow.  I never knew of a place serving bone marrow still in bone before in my life.  Growing up the only time I ate bone marrow was when my mom made pho and we would eat the marrow from the bone to make the soup base.  The bone marrow was delicious at St John's.  Simple, just it and some toast, a little bit of acid from the lemon and sea salt on top.  So good!  The wine selection here goes well with the food they serve.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

aUZ1VQx9O6i5eMnZjpJ5tg.text: Our seating was at 9:30pm, which is a bit late for me usually for dinner.  But am I ever glad I went there!   I had the bone marrow (delicious!). venison liver (best liver ever), and shared an half dozen madeline with my dinner companions.  I could have eaten all the madeline by myself, but I had to share.The liver was the best liver I ever tasted. It was cook to perfection.  I am glad I ordered it for it was the last portion of the night.  If I ever to go back to London again, I would totally go back.

DVGFuiuKVl97PKMqNm1jlw.text: Get the bone marrow! St. John's has a great way of turning the random bits into pure deliciousness - definitely must stop by if in the neighborhood.

5hB9_rkjkZYz-MZCacVejA.text: When my husband and I decided to visit London for a week, we were most excited to eat at St. John! We're fans of Fergus Henderson and were really curious to visit his restaurant. Luckily there was place - for the entire week there was only one timeslot available! So we quickly booked our reservation.A few reviewers have described the restaurant well as unassuming. We actually passed the restaurant by accident when trying to find it. When you enter there is a bar and bakery downstairs and it was packfull when we came for our 6:30pm reservation. At first we were nervous that we couldn't get a table, but luckily we soon realized the restaurant is upstairs!I was really curious to see the menu because online it changes daily. The menu ranged from safe to daring. I mean, it is a restaurant that specializes in offal. For starters my husband took the famous roasted bone marrow with toast and parsley salad and it was amazing. I love venison and celeriac, so when I saw the combo together I had to take it as my starter.Now for the mains... This is where I wanted to be a bit daring. I had read about British faggots, which are basicaly meatballs made from the kidney, liver, and heart of the animal of choice, and decided to order the goat faggots. It was a lot of newness for me, but I thought if I'm going to try them, this is the place. I can't say I loved them but it was all a part of the experience. I did love my husband's dish - roasted pork shoulder with trotters and prunes - yum!So not only did we enjoy the food, but the staff was so friendly and helpful! And questions we had about the menu everyone (not just our waitress) was more than willing to help!So if you're headed to London and want real British food, you must come to St. John!

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Venison with a salad of celeriac
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Cabbage and potatoes
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Goat faggots with root mash

hIaWtjEOKugM6MiTzQGRAw.text: The final verdict on the pronunciation is in... "Saint John" not "Sinjin" much to the dismay of my  teenage nephew, brother-in-law and husband (who have retained their teenage-glib till this day)The pheasant and trotter pie was the big hit, as was the melt in your mouth marrow of bone with brown bread and parsley. The octopus salad was polarizing from real disgust to actual fans... You must like octopus to enjoy. The giancale (pork cheek) with dandelion was also a crowd fave...maybe the best surprise of all was the Eccles cakes for desserts which my in-laws informed me was also referred to as hamentaschen (sic)... Think pot pie with sweet prunes. Surprising and delightful

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Great space
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

ZoI0I_H2BOrDzX4dWonp0A.text: St. Johns is the top of the culinary meat mountain for "Meatatarians" of the world. I started with welsh rarebit which was disTINKtingly strong and most delicious. Lamb sweetbreads were superb and readyed me for what I trekked to St. Johns to sample. For (desert) I ordered the roasted marrow bones with parsley salad and toast... OMG this was a simple but stellar dish.This and the other dishes that I sampled left me in awe of the masterful creator of these dishes, Fergus Henderson, who with his "nose to tail" cooking philosophy  has made this restaurant a gastronomic paradise for eclectic foodies from all over the world

OG7q-OWS7N46L5lTbr9hWw.text: After much anticipation, I was excited (even a little scared) about our dinner for St. John.  Having seen pictures about the various animal parts, strange dishes, and other weird but delicious food, I was going into this with a very open mind.  I will caveat things right by saying that a) I'm an American, who doesn't venture too far beyond meat and potatoes for a main and b) as a result of the former, I tend to think that I have a rather "limited" palate when it comes to various types of game.Ok, so anyway, now that I've put that out there, here's what went down during our meal.  The scene wasn't what i was expecting, it was on the louder side, but very casual, and very open-aired.  Service right from the onset was mediocre.  In aggregate, our waitress probably visited our table about 4 times the whole time we were there, some of which was a function of us trying to flag her down.  Anyway, we had scoped out the menu beforehand so we knew almost right away what we were going to be ordering.For the appetizers, we ordered the following:Brown shrimp and cabbage salad: When they say "shrimp", they mean itty bitty bay shrimp, not the shrimp you get in shrimp cocktail (those are prawns).  The salad was fresh and light, but not anything to write how about.Bone marrow salad:  WELL OF COURSE WE WERE GOING TO GET THIS.  The components of this dish were outstanding together.  The bones were served hot with a few pieces of toast, some parsley salad and onion, with some sea salt on the side.  The bone marrow comes out spreadable on the toast, and when you make yourself a small sandwich, this is absolutely delicious.  The only qualm I have about this dish is that it's definitely on the messy side.  You will DEFINITELY need your napkin.Mains:Greg had a venison dish served with a side of mash, and I ordered the grousse.Here's where my naive mind thought of prior to ordering:  Grousse, being a bird, must be similar to chicken.Reality check: Grousse and chicken may both be birds, but that's about as far as it goes in terms of similarity.  There was a fair amount of clove spices on the bird, and I absolutely butchered it throughout the process trying to find bits and pieces that were edible.  Grousse meat is most definitely game-y in my opinion.  It's dark, with a lot of "nature" tastes to it.  Although I thought I did a good job getting through most of it, I'd be lying if I said that I completely enjoyed it.  Again, maybe this is because I'm just not used to eating overly gamey meats, but I just couldn't turn the corner and start enjoying it.  Greg, on the other hand, seriously enjoyed his venison dish.  We had gone to Harwood Arms for dinner earlier on, and Greg thought his dish a St John outdid his dish at Harwood.Desserts:Buttermilk pudding: Holy cow this was delicious.  Not really 5 star delicious, but it was definitely good!  I would certainly order this againBlackberry swirl ice cream: what surprised me the most about this was how much ice cream they gave you!  That was seriously impressive!Anyway, after all of this, I just couldn't get around the idea that I didn't really enjoy my main.  I don't want to be overly critical of the place since some of this may certainly be a function of my palate, but it seems to me that places where I've given 4+ stars out is because i was blown away with whatever main I had.  I guess I don't quite get that here.  Overall, I thought this was a 5 star experience, but only a 3 star assessment for the food.

Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Buttermilk Pudding with prunes
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Welsh rarebit

ifqrf1f6joNr8tN0LRQ_PQ.text: Full disclosure: This is my favorite restaurant. But they're not paying me to say that.I've eaten at St John (this Smithfield location) at least ten times, and I don't even live in the UK. It is my most anticipated meal (and second meal) every trip I take to London. The food and the beer selection are flawless time after time, and I love that it's located close to my favorite pub (the Jerusalem Tavern). You do not need a reservation to eat in the "bar," which is where I have dined all but one time, if it's just you or you plus one. I think that you get a full dinner menu in the "restaurant," but to be honest the food available in the bar is what I'm after anyway! Come right around 5pm to get your pick of tables and enjoy a very relaxing meal. The early-evening atmosphere here, at least in summer, is fantastic.And as far as atmosphere, St John is supremely comfortable. I have usually eaten here alone, and never felt awkward or out of place. The bar and the dining room are both more casual than you might expect; I once wore a dress and heels here and felt overdressed. The space is minimally decorated and the focus is 100% on the food. I think that the reasonable prices reflect this; there's no "fine dining" posturing here.I can't leave without eating two things: the roast bone marrow and the terrine. These dishes have been consistent meal after meal, year after year, and are two of the most deliciously satisfying menu items you will ever taste. Another favorite when available is the pigskin salad. I once ate two orders of it, in addition to roast bone marrow and Welsh rarebit, by myself. When I brought my father here, we ordered ox heart with chips, and it was also wonderful. Brown shrimp on toast, snails & chorizo, grilled sprats with celeriac salad, eccles cake & cheese... it has all been great.I understand that they have a good wine list here, but I am only interested in beer. They usually offer Meantime ales, which I happen to love, and the servers never get pushy with wine or with "pairing" my food, which I appreciate. Speaking of the servers, they deserve a word. All but one time, the service at St John has been excellent for me. That one time that was an exception, I had a waiter who was quite condescending and didn't check on us/bring the check for nearly 30 minutes after serving main courses. I can't drop my review because of the one time, and I have not seen that server at the restaurant again.In my opinion, this is not an overpriced dining spot. I am never shocked when I see the amount show up in USD$ on my bank statement, and I have never once felt ripped off. A joy every time... and I'll be back in October!

lUWgWRK9g2v2jxa-0ZOpIQ.text: The waitress was surly and really put a dent in our enjoyment. I've made bone marrow at home that is exactly the same as here. Don't know what the fuss is about in that regard. The vegetables and beans were bland. The beef cheek was cooked properly, but still bland. Will not return, mostly due to the service/attitude.

oEKTJGDr8lg0pMlgYRh-zA.text: This place is absolutely fantastic. The food was wonderful!The rabbit and pork are excellent.The welsh rarebit is incredible. The freshly baked madeleines are outstanding.The service is great. I also love the atmosphere that is both smart and casual.I never had such a great dinner.

t1hNGYOt8RsAnR__imbjvg.text: Great spot tucked away on a quiet street in Smithfield. Would recommend to go on the weekend if you are looking for something quieter. Enjoyed the bar service and menu with olives, bone marrow and the cheese plate.

C6Ku0fyumNiDXzqPzZbH4w.text: I wanted some traditional British food and I love offal so when friends recommended this place I made sure to drop by. I was able to snag a table in the bar. After consulting the waiter on what to get, I chose the Welsh Rarebit and Deviled Kidneys. Wow. The rarebit is like a grilled cheese with a slightly bitter gravy. Was awesome. The Kidneys were in a flavorful rich sauce and were perfectly cooked.

qXoeSiMAKD1HLoE4HFkV1g.text: Yes, it hit the spot! If you are the mood for bone marrow, ox hearts and other non traditional dishes, this might satisfy the taste buds.  Highlights:  Delicious non traditional dishes, Ample quantity, Great Desserts, Reasonably priced wine list, Takes reservations, Great customer service and nice big dinning area.Can improve:  Would love to see some more birds on the menu, Chicken or Duck.  A tad bit pricey.  Also, the whole pig is a highlight and they should make that available to normal dining.  How hard can it be to make 2 available every night or on your busy nights.  You can even have an option where folks can pool reservations so you have the count for the pig.  Benchmark:  They are definitely one of a kind and the reason why we dined there was so celebrate a special occasion.  Not sure, if you can do an apple to apples comparison.Dined in March 2016 and not sure if I would return.

e7IRloaP3xV0DD8KVaUKcQ.text: We went there just because the menu sounded very interesting ! The place is cozy , simple and can be good for any occasion . The menu is definitely unique ! Lamb's brains , bone marrow ,pig's tongue , lamb's kidneys - those are just a few things that we tried ! Was simple and exquisite!

Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Lamb's brains on a toast and pig's tongue
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Lamb's kidneys

tKwvOwo5x0tpnagv_7oB-Q.text: i'm a huge anthony bourdain fan so as soon as i booked my vacation to London...eating at St. John was at the top of my to-do list haha. it was easy to get a reservation a couple months out on Open Table UK and even though we showed up a few minutes early for our reservation, we were seated right away. the host was super friendly and immediately asked to take our jackets (really cool that there are so many coat hangers around the restaurant too haha). our server was really helpful too at explaining certain dishes on the menu to us since we had never heard of some of the entree items haha.we started with a bottle of the St. John Cabernet that was really easy to drink and for our appetizers, had to order the bone marrow along with the smoked cod's roe on toast. both were absolutely delicious! the fresh baked bread along with the salad on the bone marrow made the dish actually refreshing to me and i was surprised at how much i liked the smoked cod's roe dish. it wasnt overly salty like i imagined and i quite liked it. for my main dish, i ordered the venison haunch. this was a first for me and i absolutely loved it. the venison was cooked a beautiful medium rare and didnt taste game-y or anything to me. overall this was definitely a highlight of my London visit. from start to finish, it was an amazing meal. i was proud of myself for trying a lot of new/different items that i normally would never order haha. it's definitely not a cheap meal, but well worth the splurge - vacation or not!

HzHBnnH3hjGkF52PfuUfWQ.text: Came as we were in the area, and glad we did!Just at the end of lunch, and a nice menu and some great dishes on offer, and the crowd is having a great time, and the server is friendly and helpful and we had a great meal. The baked good were fantastic.Enjoy!

GEKQ_qquSKUsvKMLuDus-Q.text: This place is very unsuspecting from the facade but I like this place so damn much that it was one of the most memorable meals of my recent trip to London. The interior is downplayed and understated. The atmosphere is somewhat rustic and unpretentious. It was like the chef and owner decided to turn a small market or industrial warehouse into a worthy restaurant. And worthy it is of its one Michelin star rating.The menu changes daily and St John's concept is nose-to-tail eating. So if you're in for trying offal and innards, you're in for a delicious time here. Even if you're not so into offal, still give it a try-- who knows, you might leave as a convert?Roasted bone marrow: Very, very good. Spread it on your toast, sprinkle some sea salt over it, and garnish with parsley.Lamb testicles: Is ok to brag that I've eaten lamb testicles now?! It was the special of the day so I'm assuming they don't have that everyday. Bbattered and deep fried, they came with a side of strong garlic dip. The testicles very definitely interesting and had a solid texture to it. I really liked the strong garlic dip with the fried testicles.Crispy pig cheek and dandelion: I dreamt for days about the pig cheeks after our meal at St John. The pieces of pig cheeks came with the pork crackling attached. The crackling was perfect and crisp, and the meat from the cheek melted in the mouth. Such contrasting textures... and so memorable.Braised tripe:Prior to this, I've only had tripe at Chinese, Vietnamese, and Japanese restaurants and they're usually on the chewy side with a crunch. Not at St John. The tripe here is the smoothest, most tender, and softest I've had. If anyone gets nervous at the thought of eating tripe and hasn't tried it yet, St John's braised tripe is an excellent introduction to one's palate. The braised dish came with white beans and pieces of pork belly. It was deep in flavor.Definitely worth a return trip.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Roasted bone marrow

49IksYbGcGHLgdh8J8QLnQ.text: A real treat as always.Started with brown crab meat on toast, which was very goodFollowed with roasted bone marrow on polaine toast with a delicious onion saladAnd then gorged on roasted hake, fantastically freshExcellent meal

gK_oy5KOeJDt5E6HqGb0Ig.text: It's a bar, it's a bakery and it's a restaurant. And this place is known for the variety of exotic meats and I came here for the famous bone marrow salad.You will not get any more fat from any other substance in the world except from the bone marrow found here. It's a very nice consistency of an almost gelatin like, but liquidity fatty goodness.And when you couple that with a few pinches of sea salt, you will feel like you are in another dimension filled with candies, unicorns and rainbows.But once I got out of that fatty hallucination, I decided to go on with the main course with the braised rabbit, bacon and mustard. This dish definitely got me back to a normal balance. Definitely not as fatty as the bone marrow. But at least it was filled with the necessary proteins to overcome said fattiness from earlier.And the rabbit was nice and tender. It was more like a minestrone soup that came with some beans. This is a good choice if you come here.  I highly recommend coming down here and trying out some of their exotic items on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Braised rabbit, bacon and beans
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow and salad

sZkpK_BhnS-DAUZckXc5Fg.text: nope, nope, nope.Disappointing in several ways.  First of all, for a place with a pig as its mascot and "snout to tail" as its motto, there was no pig on the menu.  No snout.  No tail.  Nothing at all.Second, the dishes our party ordered were all mediocre at best.  Ox liver was two thin slices of liver, served dry over some plain beets.  Not tasty.  Hospital food.  Sweetbreads were so very ordinary.  And on and on.  Dishes were served neither with interesting sauces or spices, nor were they served with an emphasis on fresh, delicious, and plain cuts cooked simply to emphasize their simple deliciousness.  Preparation of our 3 apps and 3 mains reminded me of the kind of mindfulness that goes into college dining-hall food and airplane food.  The desserts we saw on our neighbors' plates looked pretty boring, so we didn't bother.Third, the service was terrible.  We waited so very long between our dishes, and at no point during the meal did a waiter ask us how it was going.  Our waitress disappeared for a long time, and we could see her eating something in the kitchen.  We finished our drinks, and no server was around for at least 30 minutes, to ask us if we wanted another.  Don't they want to make money?  (Oddly, when the waitress was clearing our dishes at the end of the meal she asked if I would like another glass of wine.  Yes I did!  45 minutes ago when you were absent!)What a failure.  We watched a beautiful roast suckling pig being carried past us and into another room.  Maybe the VIP's in that room were receiving the food and the service I had been expecting?  The black pudding and breakfast sausage I had with my breakfast fry-up at my local pub was better than anything I had at St John tonight!  And HP sauce would have improved most of this bland and unimaginative food.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Two bland slices of liver, served with beets and cheesy horseradish.  So disappointing.

y3sCQuHeGgJl2Y4_fIvKqw.text: We did our best to not be disappointed. We really did.My husband and I aren't famous or overly hipsterish. We're not British. What we are are lovers of great food and great wine and warm hospitality at reasonable prices. So whenever we travel, that's we look for.We chose St. John to end a long week of business/sightseeing in London on the always dependable recommendation of another Bay Area foodie friend. We willingly accepted a late reservation on a Friday, and prepared ourselves for what we were sure would be a memorable end to our trip.When we arrived for our 9:30 reservation, the gracious but harried house manager asked if we'd mind waiting at the bar a few minutes for our table. We waited for nearly half an hour, checking out the hipster crowd which added color and spice to the austere decor. We also had plenty of time to watch as a waiter began drawing lines through all the bar menu dishes no longer available. As the manager apologized for the wait and seated us in the dining room, making reference to a "crazy night",  I made a point of saying that I knew the wait would be worth it and not to worry.Soon our waitress came by and, with a lot of grace, proceeded to take us down the menu to note all the things *they* were out of (it was at least a quarter of the menu). The menu formatting didn't help us recognize some of the dish components on our own, so we had to ask for her her help, which she cheerfully gave, even though she was working several large parties, as well as one table very close to us where a seriously A-list British actor was sitting with a friend. She apologized for being so bus,  and mentioned that they'd been understaffed all night. Once again, I was gracious and reassured her that dining within spitting distance of [famous name omitted because he's apparently a regular] was consolation enough. I meant it. At least, I wanted to mean it.We settled on our dishes, only for the waitress to have to come back and offer substitution suggestions because, what do you know, they were out of some of what we'd ordered. So how was the food?My husband's salad with the substituted crispy pig's skin was fantastic, while my starter of a series of small whole fish with horseradish potatoes was great too (even if I had to crunch my way through quite a few bones. Didn't have the courage to ask if that was as designed or not).My rabbit dish was good, although in what I'm sure it typical for this kind of eating, a little unwieldy and not yielding as much edible rabbit as I'd hoped.The sauce was delicious, but the garlic was certainly on the aggressive side.Can't remember my husband's main dish, but the a la carte greens we ordered to accompany it (because in typical British fashion, it's an a la carte menu) were good, albeit tough/possibly undercookedA different waiter came by to take our dessert order and when I tried to ask him about the backstory on the name of one dish, he was more than a little snide and just too cool for words. In the end, the dessert options seemed rather pedestrian and while our molten chocolate cake was great (and large!), it wasn't anything new or different to be sure. By the time we finally flagged someone down to pay the bill, it was past eleven o'clock. (That plus the good bottle of wine we had likely explains why I literally can't remember what my husband's main course was. Again, trying to be charitable.)The pricing for our meal was far from unreasonable, which is a major plus for a city that still charges a pretty penny/pound for a good meal, even with the favorable exchange rate. But what surprised me was, after all the crazy - the long wait, the shambles of a menu - not a thing was comped. Nary an apology was offered. They just took our money and that was that. I won't begin to know what caused them to run out of so much of their menu and be so short staffed on a Friday night. I don't think the level of experience we had was just because we weren't as famous as Mr. Famous Actor at the next table. But what I do know is if a Ruth Reichl or Pete Wells-type reviewer had had our experience, they'd unload one of their "over hyped, underwhelming" reviews on the place. I know good restaurants have bad nights. I also know that good restaurants acknowledge they're having a bad night with something other than a few mumbled words of apology. I did have a good story to tell my kids about seeing You Know Who from those movies they love, though.

GVmILupww4-op4yq_J6A8w.text: GO! Okay, I admit it, walking into this place was a little bit off-putting. The basic white exterior is lackluster, the way inside isn't quite clear, and the stark white interior was quite asylum-like. But wow, the food. There was not one bad bite in our very large meal. I had the snail salad and the rabbit. There was just the right amount of snail in the salad, and it didn't have that "a little too natural" taste that is sometimes a turn-off, it was delicious. The rabbit was perfection, and I was "this close" to ordering another one. My partner got the pork terrine and a fish plate (which he said was "cooked and sliced perfectly"). My partner raved about how the fish was prepared actually, I should point out ("expertly sliced" he said once or twice). We both had stupid smiles on our faces this entire meal. "Oh my god, you have to try this ..." that kinda thing.The whole thing was presently wonderfully by our waiter, Jon,  who was very knowledgeable and honest with his suggestions and helping us decide what to get in the first place. He was also just plain adorable - tall and adorable.Finally, desserts. I got the Honey/Walnut Ice Cream. GET IT. It's an ice cream that eats like a meal all by itself. It was chunky, hearty and a perfect "winter" ice cream, if that makes sense. My partner's pear sorbet was also great. So, yeah. Go!

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Pear sorbet and vodka, like peanut butter and jelly.
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Honey/Walnut Ice Cream. Just do it.

R-xtRf8Ts3lZt0WSjpGDQw.text: WOW! Thanks again for never failing me, Yelpers! This place was sooo worth it and more. Modern British fare with a warehouse attitude and good service. The bone marrow was everything and more; delectable and oddly delicate, there was enough in that appetizer my husband ordered for both of us. I had the pig's head terrine which was good but not as good as the marrow. And it only got better from there.You must be a meat-eater to appreciate this tail-to-hoof restaurant or why bother coming? Yes, they have greens but that's not their speciality. And be adventurous for god sake's or just go down to the local pub and have a meat pie. This is a foodie joint, true to the word. Even the waitress got excited explaining the entrees (it's cuz she saw me do my Happy Food Dance). Anyway, absolutely worth all the accolades. We would have come again but it does put a dent in your wallet and London is already one of the most expensive cities in the world so the one time was bliss.

-Kw9udG5N5tCes5iJGMhnQ.text: A great place. I went in for lunch in a skeptic state of mind (the menu looks a bit spartan), but I loved every second of it. The place is relaxed and airy, staff and customers are chilled and diverse (I was afraid I was going to be in the middle of an ocean of suits, but it was actually very informal) the food was excellent and the service one of the fastest Ive seen in expensive restaurants. We had the marrow bone, bloodcake and ox heart and everything was fautless, tasty and unfussy. I would hapilly eat anything that comes out of that kitchen. Their freshly baked madeleines are sublime, a glorious ending to any meal. Overall, definitively recommended. It is a bit pricey, but not too much if you bear in mind the location, teh standards and the fact that it is a bit of an institution (70 quid for two with some beer and wine, and I can think of places where you pay twice as much and you dont leave as happy as we lwere after our lunch at St Johns).

B4XwYA9_fydr_QqBp1oBKA.text: St. John's has got to be one of my favourite spots in the area, a must-go if you're a carnivore. The whole suckling pig requires advance notice and a fairly large party, but is unmissable. They're one of the few places I've visited that serves bone marrow. They also do 'normal' food for the squeamish, but for people who aren't afraid of offal, there's nowhere like it!

IaUzCaYZ7p6vskhNQVGiwA.text: pig cheek alone was 5 stars. bread was so good. good service, with a decor of emptiness! my friend and i hypothesized that it was to focus attention on the food not the ambiance.. white, chipped walls, chipped wooden floors, white table cloths on wooden tables.. simplicity. go eat pig cheek. (and cheap!)

09reaAyM8UeYQl_BS99TFw.text: Being from SoCal... London is all about getting cozy in the dreary weather.... Bone marrow is cozy.... English culture & food is cozy.... Hell.. THE SMITHS are cozy...

zUNL0qn1FGBO-z4GSwGVyw.text: As I've mentioned in other reviews - and which bears repeating - I am a worthy disciple of the St John restaurant.  St John's (or chef Fergus Henderson's) famed ethos of "nose to tail eating" has transformed British cuisine - at least among foodies (and particularly restaurant critics).  It is now a gastronomic pleasure to seek out and indulge in delicacies such as ox tongue, calf brains, kidneys and bone marrow.  But while I'm a liver-eating fool and have loved bone marrow since first trying it years ago (in NYC), even I recoil a bit at certain offal (ie, head cheese).  And fortunately, St John is about much more than eating nasties... it's about no-frills, fresh, local and seasonal food - think purple sprouting tops, squid and tomatoes, squash soup, lancashire cheese.That said, you really need to love meat to eat at St John.  You can't quiver if you see them oiling up a suckling pig, fresh from the local butcher.  Indeed, you should want to eat the pig - but be sure to reserve one (apparently there are only 3 available per night and sadly, I have not had the pleasure).  If you're with a group for a special occasion (St John is perfect for larger parties) and can't share a pig, indulge in the feasting menu which offers choices of dishes, shared family-style.  A recent visit yielded their famous and delicious roast bone marrow (served plainly, with parsley, capers, rock salt and toast), a simple block of fois gras, roast beef with horseradish cream, roast chicken with bread sauce (slightly boring) and a decadent, sloppy dessert of Eccles Cake and Chocolate "Terrine" (a melded dark chocolate brick) with creme fraiche.  Yes, we were full.  Note:  St John sources its amazing bread from sister restaurant/bakery St John Bread & Wine, another go-to for top-notch food (in a more casual atmosphere).

_tVN6ooMWUj3WrEevWUUKQ.text: My gastronomic Mecca.  I must eat here every time I visit London, and if I can't get a table then either St. John Bread & Wine in spitalfields or The St. John Hotel in Leicester Square will serve as a back-up plan. It's not a place for people with Selective Eating Disorder, Texture issues Ora preconceived notion of what tastes good. Everything is delicious at this nose to tail temple.

OOtXeTXmBU3P9i4G-R9Mpg.text: Just a lil' review  was great!

0tRz-Zm8bpYT7repb2pRjA.text: made reservations for this place b/c it was highly suggested by a friend and b/c it got great reviews including a michelin rating AND its #43 on the list of top 50 restaurants in the world (2nd in uk) theworlds50best.com/awar…we were able to make reservations the week of on open table... but at 10pm on a thursday night :( whatever. it was fine. i can delay dinner if i know its going to be good. when we arrived the place was still packed but we were one of the last tables to leave close to midnight. the service was a BIG downer to this restaurant. at first we really liked the atmosphere and the service because it was unpretentious and wasn't overly stuffy and proper as is most highly rated restaurants. the guests were loud, happy, and didnt scream rich. however, our waitress was a different matter. we told her upfront that we didnt know how to go about the menu and even what most dishes on the menu were. she was very helpful but it felt reluctant and she definitely wasn't friendly or smiley. more b/c she HAD to.. and you could feel that in her tone and attitude.another thing that got me was that even though she basically ordered our whole meal. not ONCE did she come by and ask us how the food was. not ONCE. even at the cheapest restaurants the waiter will come over to inquire. she did occasionally glance over to check on us.. but maybe this is just service in london!? highly doubtful.. she finally cover over when it was obvious that we were done with our meal and gave us our dessert. THEN to add on top of that, sometime between the time that we were eating dessert and done with our meal, she left or at least disappeared from sight. usually waiters will at least leave the bill or let us know that they will be leaving but nope. she was just gone. so we were left waiting. and had to flag another waiter down to get our bill... very disappointed. now onto the MOST important part the food. was delicious! we ordered: - BONE MARROW - a special tool is provided to scoop out all the goodness inside the bone and add a bit of salt and leaves. BEST thing there. dont add too much salt b/c its strong. - OX TONGUE - surprisingly veryy good as well. definitely try this. - venison offal - not so good. perhaps b/c we just didnt like offal. its internal organs if you dont know.. the sauce was decent though- BRAISED MALLARD (wild duck) - came with meat and wing. the meat was a bit tough but still tasted good. the wing was better. would suggest this. - fronton reser red wine - great. went well with our meat- sprout tops - for just veggies. this was good, although hard to cut - chocolate terrin & milk toffee ice cream with waffle cracker - chocolate was too rich. the ice cream and waffle cracker was delicious!!! three combined tries to balance the richness of the chocolate but is unsuccessful. however it is much tastier if you eat all three in the same bitewas very surprised this restaurant didnt have a tasting menu so we just ordered a la carte and shared. the entrees were just okay to me. the appetizers was definitely the highlight of our meal!! as a top 50 restaurant in the WORLD, i would have expected a bit more. however the food is VERY UNIQUE and definitely worth a try.

xNEo43_r2Rflhie2LzEHfg.text: We checked out St. John's following Anthony Bourdain's recommendation, and we were definitely pleased. Out of all the English restaurants we've tried in London, this was perhaps the only truly excellent (and one of the few even decent) establishments we visited. Our dishes were the lamb tongue and bone marrow appetizers, along with braised chicken with bacon and mashed potatoes and breaded veal entrees. For dessert, we split a sumptuous apple crisp. Every one was spectacular, particularly the bone marrow. On any subsequent trips to London, I will always make a point to come back to St. John's - it gets points for being a memorable restaurant in London's mostly bleak gastronomic scene.

yO9H7n0epBAtOWSxJq855w.text: My friend invited me to have dinner here one evening, and after taking a look at the menu and seeing several dishes I didn't recognize, I was a bit skeptical. I decided to give it a try, though, after reading all the positive reviews of the restaurant on Qype and other websites. May I just say that the service was lovely? This was my friend and my first visit, so we had MANY questions to ask our waiter. He was ever so patient and explained everything we wanted to know in detail. He knew his stuff. We finally decided on the bone marrow salad to start, and for mains, my friend ordered the guinea fowl, and I the lemon sole. The food was exquisite. We both wiped our plates clean. The bone marrow salad, to my surprise, was incredibly delicious -- a bit oily, but delicious, nonetheless. It was served with a few pieces of toasted bread (heaven in itself). If you are looking for a unique and tasty experience, I would highly recommend you give this restaurant a try.

8VK5308hBhimYJXJLCG9Mw.text: Be sure to book, but you'd definitely won't regret going. I love this place!

Gf6gb5lLXJdLAR6Ex1_yQw.text: My first Impression about this place was great and the crowded like every other place on a sat night. The drinks were typical. I had fun that night. Good times w/ friends for my home boy's birthday bash.

ciI-TLDorbDTLfSmpc6YyQ.text: We went to St. John in mid-September for an evening dinner. My companion had the onion/bacon soup as a starter and skate as a main with a glass of the Vignobles Guillaume 2008 pinot; I had the octopus starter with a glass of Mas d'Auzieres 2008 rose and mutton main with a glass of Eric Texier 2007 Cote du Rhone.  The positives: the soup was superbly rich and was characterized as "liquid bacon", the skate was succulent (but I have not tried skate before so don't have any benchmarks), and the mutton was very nicely done; tender and with a pleasant amount of gamey funk (but I have never tried mutton before, so etc). The negatives: I felt the octopus was a bit overcooked and its dressing too bright; the main accompaniments (swede with the mutton, and a caper sauce with the skate) tasted nice enough but were otherwise unremarkable.  The wine pairings were my own choice so I can't levy criticism there. :) We ordered an additional side of cabbage and potatoes which was pleasantly buttery.Water and bussing staff were generally attentive.My primary criticism is with the service; while the host was welcomingand charming, the waitstaff for our table was distracted and distant and our interaction with them was devoid of even the most perfunctory pleasantries.  Overall, the experience didn't match up to other Michelin-starred restaurants at which I've eaten, but I'd recommend it to others based on the competence of the kitchen and the relatively reasonable price point.

v3oxm12IPkWuVwfN2iJG3Q.text: Excellent food and good service with friendly staff and a refreshing informal atmosphere, top notch dining!

tv9RZgAEx0sIKmybj8ndXw.text: I booked a reservation online before going on Holiday to London a few months back. I was surprised to get a response as quickly as I did. Seeing as how my BF and I are foodies, we had to eat at St John's on our holiday. We knew we picked the right place to eat because a local Briton told us as we were walking towards the door that St John's was one of the best restaurant in England. He was correct. Seeing as how the US dollar had such a low exchange rate, we were tried to budget. Our apps were marrow salad with parsley for the BF, parsnip soup with back fat for myself.  Both dishes were very unique. We of course shared a little. The marrow came in the bones, fresh out of the oven. A nice little parsley salad with shallots and capers was served on the side, as well as some nice country bread. The one bite I had was very tasty. I only took one bite because I had an issue with the texture of the marrow ( a personal problem lol) He loved it! My soup was nice. the back fat added so much to the soup, it was just amazing to eat them together. My only complaint was the small portion of back fat, about 4 little pieces. The soup was amazing with them, but not my favorite without the fat. I had a braised squirrel for my entree, and the BF had chitterlings with radish ( thats pig stomach for you folks watching at home)  I hadn't had squirrel before, it was really interesting! I liked it, but it was so gamey I got full pretty fast. I'm not used to such gaminess, it was good but a little much. I tasted a bite of the chitterlings and was glad I didn't get them. They were ok, not really my type of food. We both really loved the vibe of the restaurant. St John's has an incredible menu as we spent a long time deliberating on what to order. Its short and simple, but very creative. They cook simple food, but very out of the ordinary for the American palette. I really liked that. It was really fun to see a menu and have no idea what anything tastes like, it's a great way to develop a palette. Too full and a tad ill, we skipped dessert ( budget too) It was a wonderful experience, a place I would eat at if I happen to be in London again anytime soon.

SiyitzhUozWnRTgQvm7_lg.text: I have been there last Sat and had a great night!The staff was just lovely

kkppuzSuXFojiKnUffvlHw.text: What do they call it? Head to tail eating. Well here every bits from head to tail can be experienced and tasted. Simple cooking methods, fresh ingredients and great food without boundaries and pre-conceptions! I love St John; I can't stress enough about this place! Crispy Pig's Skin & Dandelion is great to start and they do whole roast sucking pig if you order in advance(quite expensive though, £320 for a whole pig) but it is really good and truly recommended!!! Try it and you will know what I mean! A real feast this one! They do Christmas puddings and mince pies too check it out maybe something for Christmas!

Opj8mStHNIunwxCiIyjyeA.text: Very highly recommended, not just great food but a great overall experience

aHKxqd4J1JZOpTYgigOYDQ.text: For a long time, I have been looking for a good traditional restaurant in London. Finally my friends took me to St John Restaurant. I took a braised rabbit peas and bacon and I particularly enjoyed it. They offer a wide selection of traditional meals and their wine list is massive. A very nice place.

PpNEwSy5QZ0l6dsLMJR74Q.text: Great leisurely summer lunch at a very good restaurant. The bone marrow and parsley salad with toast is everything that Anthony Bourdain says it is. It's rich and luscious and delicious.  The grilled ox heart with picked long beans was equally tasty. Perfectly cooked to maximize flavor, while keeping the heart meat tender and soft.  Dessert was surprisingly good as well. Try the madeleines - they bake them to order every time - amazing with some coffee. They were so good, we took a couple dozen to go. Price was reasonable - especially for a michelin starred place. Why 4 stars? The service was aloof and a little cool for my taste. Adequate, but not superb.

g-hxbd9asYJwPGJictdmnA.text: A chef's restaurant! Offal is not generally for the faint of heart. Of course the roasted bone marrow the parsley and grilled bread is delicious, but where this place really shines if the other organ meats cooked to perfection. It's not cheap, but come on it is one of the best in the world. I just read the chef/owner is opening a hotel of the same name now too.

IHuloNYJ8GHg5GMAllrdww.text: I do love restaurants like this down to earth and this one was great keep it upsee you soon.

xbBLZV_We0IN1WSBCi5U6g.text: I died and went to heaven here.  This is my kind of place.  While planning our trip to London, I came across a review of St. John in the NY Times.  I don't remember why I became determined to eat here, but thankfully, I did.  At the last minute, we had to reschedule our 8 pm reservation to 9:45 pm.  It was still packed when we arrived at 9:30 (on a Monday, no less).  Nice wine list.  We shared a salad that involved dandelions, Ox heart, and the Mallard.  Every dish was exceptional.  You will live an incomplete life if you pass on the Madeleines.

EH2-6pBNLeY185edqbaXWQ.text: Nose to tail eating is on offer at St. John Bar and Restaurant located (aptly enough) on St. John Street, just a short skip from Smithfield Market. Not for the squeamish, St. John's menu of traditional British fare reads like a poem for omnivorous readers eager to partake in the sampling of delectable titles, such as Grilled Squid & Green Sauce and Mince On Dripping Toast. During my visit, I shared a starter course of Roast Bone Marrow & Parsley Salad with my wife and went halves on Crumbed Veal Rump, Chicory & Anchovy and Calf''s Liver & Beetroot. Our server commended us on ordering what she considered her favorite items, and, upon our dinner's arrival, we soon congratulated each other on a meal well chosen. Open well over a decade, St. John Smithfield (they have another location at Spitalfield) exceeds at providing understated elegance of a quintessentially British nature. Appropriate attire ranges from suit-and-tie to t-shirt-and-trainers. Main courses range from £13.50-20.50. Reservations are highly recommended.

kbnZSh3i0Li8Wd4BtydfmA.text: I have come to pay homage to the restaurant that started it all...Admittedly, snout to tail eating isn't really anything new.  Not from my experience, at least.  But at St. John, it's the attention they bring to it, and the ethos of preparing food in the simplest way that made the restaurant truly special.I walked in to a stark, austere looking dining room with bare white walls, tables with white butcher paper on top, and no flowers or fancy settings to distract.  I was expecting to feel cold from all the austerity.  But instead, I felt warm from the lively atmosphere and the knowledgeable staff.  To start, a 2007 Mas d'Auzieres 'Sympathie pour les Stones' from Languedoc.  It was a marvelous GSM blend, with a tres-witty name.  I found it interesting too that St John decided to go into the wine business, and that the retail price of the wine are listed on the menu.  For starters, the Roast Bone Marrow with Parsley Salad.  I have had the bone marrow dish at a number of places elsewhere.  It was a different feeling eating the dish where it was 'invented'.  A bit of parsley and a sprinkle of rock salt really brought the richness of the marrow to another level. For mains, Middlewhite and Fennel, and Ox Heart and Chips.  I'm a big fan of porchetta, and the Middlewhite did not disappoint.  The skin seemed to have been taken off, deep fried, and then put back together on the dish.  Brilliant.  The ox heart was sliced thin, marinated, and grilled quickly.  It appropriated the texture of very very tender skirt steak.  The chips were sort of uninspired, but the side of boiled Spring Greens brought enough freshness to counter the pork and beef.  For pudding, a Nectarine & Raspberry pie.  Great tangy and sweet fruit compote under a crisp cobbler topping.  A very unique combination which made me want to attempt it at home.Why 5 stars?  My dining list in London had so many places that spawned out of St John.  Here in Chicago, and elsewhere, a slew of restaurants follow the same philosophy.  Only a handful of restaurants in the world perhaps have this kind of claim.

XWHGGr2vi-F49Rg1B2r8QA.text: Genuis in simplicity. St John is a unique restaurant serving great simple food that is beautifully executed. It is not the 10th best restaurant in the world - as suggested by one well known top 50 list - its not even 1,000th . Fergus Henderson has created a classic and long may he and it ssurvive.

m-zdBO4WBtwuifN8moD1pQ.text: Not many places really offer the sorts of dishes that St Johns does, with a focus on more local British ingredients that you rarely seen on the menu at other places. This is both its strength and weakness with so many unusual parts of an animal, or the more unique breeds listed that makes you end up feeling a little bit foolish (or more excited if you're like me) that you end up constantly asking for interpretations from the waiters. Always busy on the weekdays where mostly business people seem to be treating each other, they also have a much less formal dining area out back where you can indulge in the many other wines that they also serve. This same part also offers bread for you to buy to take home if you're so inclined. A great and unusual experience that I think everyone in London should try!

Q6epz-ERR0PiU3--EIUCmA.text: St John is one of my favourite restaurants. It is simple nose to tail cooking with the odd dish that can be challenging. My favourites over the last year or so have been Squirrel, Lambs Fry and Pheasant and Trotter Pie. The only thing I would say is that if you are squeemish then don't stay too late after lunch as they tend to unpack and prepare the fresh un-jointed carcasses. Fascinating for some but not for my vegetarian secretary who, in my opinion, knew what she was letting herself in for so I have no sympathy.

kNs-bvwPmIiPj1bNXyIWVg.text: One of the best meals I've had in London, and certainly the most hearts, livers, and assorted other innards on the table at once. I had the grouse which was *very* rare. If it hadn't been put on my plate nearly in full flight, I would have easily been convinced that the meat was very rare, tender beef. The side of heart/liver/??? pate was amazing. I also got tastes of the middlewhite, mallard and venison offal. Basically I came off this meal feeling like a caveman. Would highly recommend.

SiR0rEDHEV9kd3F-o9_mcQ.text: ever have blood cake?  you can have it here along with other meaf oddities.  i had been recommended the joint by a pal.  i had tried to have dinner here a few months ago but they were booked even though there were empty tables abound.  one of my pet peeves.  same drill the evening i went.  we ended up there for 3 hours.  partly an hour waiting for the check.  the service is amiable but you can get lost in a sea of diners.  the food was good.  i ate the entire blood cake with a perfectly fried egg a top.  i'm not a fan of oozy yolks, but i loved this one so much i lapped it up with my blood cake.  i also sampled a bit of the bone marrow starter.  i got a lot of fat.  :(  it seems like a popular starter because i saw quite a few come out of the kitchen.  st. john's does wondrous things with meaf, but the service is sporadic.

li3FlqN0IyK4MGkp4map3g.text: Loved the bone marrow on toast!  Must try again next time I'm in London - perhaps the Spitalfields location!

4u8B93BrQCk62KpwHgFMQA.text: Great traditional food. Dishes I would not normally try I have loved. It is also reasonably priced and has a good stand alone bar with an excellent variety of ales and ciders.

in1FkmuR5MR7xQXpW4F-SQ.text: This place is AMAZING for two reasons the daytime Patiserie and the evening meals Daytime: They offer a fantastic range of fresh baked cakes, breads and other things that make you drool at the sight of them. Evening: The food and range of meal options quite possibly blew me away and I wasn't disappointed by the vodka sorbet! Great place to go if you want a 'money is no object' meal

ROXNqU12B8t_7ItNpTyJHg.text: Very very good. Fantastic bone marrow, suckling pork and the desserts are remarkable. However (and I am aware this is a bit of blasphemy) I like Hereford Road better. Interestingly enough, our least favourite dinner we've had at Chez Panisse (possibly the best restaurant in America) was when Fergus Henderson was the guest chefs. Jet lag, maybe?

NwqbY2tam2BsiMfPqyY85w.text: The restaurant is tucked away above a fairly lively bar and seems at first to be quite cold and stark. However the service is warm and friendly, and the food AMAZING!Typical dishes include teal, bone marrow, tongue salad and eel, and the menu is updated twice daily on the website (for lunch and dinner) so you can prepare yourself in advance if you're not used to such traditional cuts of meat.We went for a birthday celebration expecting it to be very pricey and I was secretly dreading trying the offal but it was really delicious and came in at under £80 for two of us, with wine, having two courses each plus a shared dessert. Definitely somewhere to try if it's a special occasion and you want something a bit different.

rmr5M9cxNQaxk_iW4SwCMQ.text: Offal good. Which is to say, this is a great restaurant with a clever meaty ethos (eating the whole animal) and a great bakery that produces fresh cakes all day long, located in a clinical-white but rough ex-abattoir.

xEJgZaiU4UzxAnW11yQkfg.text: Incredible.  My meal consisted of bone marrow and parsley, green beans and duck hearts, pigs head pie, broccoli tops, potatoes and eccles cake & lancashire cheese.  Everything was delicious and satisfying.

iQcQ3oH93O4B_ILO9dt_xw.text: Nose-to-tail eating, just round the corner from Smithfield meat market. This is a no-nonsense restaurant in a former Georgian smokehouse, with whitewashed walls, mismatched chairs and tables, and a seriously carnivorous menu, with top quality English produce. The classic starter to have here is the bone marrow and parsley salad. I've had some very good fish here too, as well as dishes such as roast Middlewhite pork  there are usually only a few dishes to choose from but with the guarantee that they will be made with the best ingredients available, and done extremely well. I remember when St John opened in the mid-90s  offal, which had been considered poor food  got reinstated on the menu and there was this new movement against chucking the unwanted parts of the pig (or other animals) away as it was so wasteful. Definitely eat here, if you get the chance.

wG3G2DIjCMybhPzmPKQvJA.text: Absolutely great food, very unique and really cool design and vibe.

DfgKkQwPrzBV1IpRZAM2Rw.text: What. A. Drag. This was a restaurant of legend for us, having first heard about it in Last Supper where the late great Bourdain waxed poetic about St John's bone marrow. This is the place that defined nose to tail cooking. We were ready for it, had barely eaten all day in anticipation of it. We arrived early and had a drink at the bar and were ready for some simple unfussy food well prepared. We started with the bone marrow, pickled herring with creme fraiche, and the crab toast. All decent but nothing particularly mind blowing. The herring was easily the best thing, tangy and tart with a generous dollop of fatty cream to balance it all out. Pretty standard but well executed. The bone marrow was just fine. There was three times as much grilled bread as was necessary for such a meager bit of marrow.  I had maybe one good bite, again nothing special.  The crab toast was totally boring. All crab guts, no crab.  Also, how many starters on toast can a person eat?The mains were where the wheels fell off the train though. We were hoping for more offal, but the menu has gotten boring or at least was the night we were there. We had the tripe with chips and ketchup and ate half of it, it was just a plate of fried crap, more chicken McNuggets than cooking of any quality. The tripe was good but the preparation so greasy and overdone that it was impossible to eat more than a couple pieces. The other dish was the smoked eel with beets and horseradish. Pretty good actually - but again mystifying why they'd pair earthy meat with earthy veg and deep fried meat with deep fried veg, it was all so one note. Ultimately though the thing that pushed the whole meal from just disappointing into kind of a piss off was the service. This is no fancy joint, it's whole aesthetic is working class food, I get it. The prices aren't awful either so nobody is expecting 3 Michelin star service, but honestly I have sat for a shorter amount of time over a pile of dirty dishes or waited for a bill longer at greasy spoon diners than I have at St John. We had planned to order dessert but it took so long to have our dirty dishes cleared and for the waitress (who's first words were "are you ready to order" and who hadn't taken a drink order yet and seemed entirely over it from the moment she walked up - honestly lady if you hate your job and all your clientele that much find a new job) to come take our order that we just asked for the bill instead. In the end I had to get up and ask her to pay she was so interested in clearing the  empty tables rather than serving the ones with warm bodies in them.In one line, we came for "Nose to tail" and all we got  we "ignored and bailed".

xP7QOFCA4GqJ-CM96Zd6GQ.text: Delicious food in a relaxed and amiable environment. Umami in spades. Go. Dine. Love your life.

SfuQlYnI6OWGwYNDDXf-sA.text: Honestly, I'm not even shitting you, this was one of the best restaurant experiences of my life. I've been wanting to go here for years, and finally got the opportunity.Our server was top notch - she basically knew what we wanted, when we wanted it. She was fun but no-bullshit efficient and nailed all the recommendations. Wine, perfect and priced well.The food - my god - the food. I don't remember specifics, but get as much as you can eat. Note that the bar menu has some additional items, so when you are waiting for your table, it might be wise to start snacking. Or just have a lighter dinner in the bar area without a reservation. The kitchen is attached to the dining room, which kind of feels like you are eating at a friend's house. Some big group got the suckling pig and I almost tried to outbid them for that pig.And finally, the check came and it was a very tolerable about GBP 100 for the both of us for about 5 medium sized dishes, cocktails, and a bottle of wine.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bar menu
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Dandelion and pork skin salad

GutaKcJvzu-xAXi4qXjTWg.text: It's been five years since my initial visit to St. John, and between then and now I think it's safe to say that I have expanded my taste palate. Returning to London and having secured our reservation for a second time, I was somewhat worried that our upcoming visit to St. John would change my perspective on my amazing first experience.But fast-forward to post-visit: St. John was just as I remembered it. The WHITE CABBAGE & BROWN SHRIMP was just the same, if not better. Of course our second visit was not an opportunity lost, we had tried other dishes such as the HAM AND PEA SOUP: a bowl or heart of pure and richness. The MIDDLE WHITE (pork) with mustard and potatoes, RABBIT SADDLE, a special of the evening, and their desserts, a DOUBLE BAKED CHOCOLATE CAKE, and PEACH AND TOAST. All were equally excellent in their own way. Simple, tasty, no frills. To top it all off we also bought a bottle of their house Bourgogne. Simple, drinkable, light, just how it's supposed to be. Was the bathroom visit just as sublime as my first? There was no CK One soap, but they did have my favorite: Aesop! St. John this time around easily lived up to its first visit.
