Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

rdDn98ZfbpHiVJCL8b8iNg.text: Everything was perfect! Great Location, great service, great Food ... It was my first time eating entrails. It took me a bit to do it but everything tasted really great and I like the idea of the "nose to tail eating". Highly recommended! The Housewine was the perfect fit to our menu!

0LVKG00RmBE2R4H4Ggrb7A.text: This place is great and we ate our weight in meats. We had the bone marrow, one of their specials, duck liver on toast (this was amazing and so smooth and rich and creamy I wish I could eat this every day), asparagus with roe, poached duck leg which was a very large portion of meat, and the Cornish hen with jelly which was perfectly cooked. Of course we had dessert which was vanilla ice cream on top of quince jelly/jello. The service was excellent and our server made great recommendations and gave feedback on dishes that fit within our friend's dietary restrictions. This will be on the repeat list the next time I'm back in London.

RUNzOdAcONEXCihzEPFtjQ.text: Some hits, some misses. The oxtail soup was outstanding, as was the bone marrow. Some of the mains were quite average. The madeleines were perfectly baked, crispy with a moist inside. Service was really quite slow and inattentive, even when it wasn't that busy. Overall a good experience but nothing too special.

W76xcUHo2eEDPwR4iikgbA.text: I've been coming to St. John first since I was an expat resident in London in 2009  for a year till now... 8 years consistently. I learned about Fergus from the original Bourdain episode from the era of No Reservations and the first time was amazing. Every time has been amazing. I have made it a point to come back here every time I've been in the city no matter how short of a stay and with as many people as I can. I enjoyed it so much I kept coming back a few nights in a row and just eating solo at the bar because it's just that good. I don't think you can get this type of cooking at this level anywhere else in the world. The menu changes daily, the main courses are seasonal, the wine list is excellent, and the service is typically on point. This place is so good I don't even know how you could debate going here. Book in advance!

mkJu0zSMOZ7caNOevqMEnw.text: As we entered into a bright white interior with a whiff of baked goods and beers, the ambience and laughter of after-work drinkers at the ground floor brought my excitement up for the food from the Dining Room. We were seated against one corner of the restaurant which was rather spectacular as we could overlook the entire space, and the presentation of staff and dishes were on point. For starters we ordered artichokes and snail soup, fried skate cheeks, and fried lamb brains. The soup was amazingly buttery and full of texture, the cheeks were relatively soft and light in flavour with a not so  acidic tomato sauce, and the fried brains was remarkably velvety and crispy with a floral egg salad on the side. For the mains we had a hare saddle and brill with chips - the hare was served pink and seared to a caramelised brown on the edges, with a red wine vinaigrette salad on the side it contrasted the heavy flavour of the red meat. The brill was fried to a perfect crisp on the skin and a thick juicy chunk of meat all throughout the slice, with a sharp garlic mayo as accompaniment with the thick-cut chips. For desserts we ordered an Eccles Cake and Lancashire Cheese, which was a perfect combo of sweet and savoury finish to the meal - the cake was bursting festive flavours! Also a Blood Orange Pavlova which I think it was a little heavy handed on the alcohol because the bites even with granola sprinkles tasted slightly bitter without the blood orange.Overall it was a fantastic dining experience and I would love to come back and try more of their finger-licking dishes!

L4Q7lhmD0meYbAc0vm7wyA.text: The service was impeccable, the food mostly unmatched. Wholly satisfied, we had the marrow bones, pigeon and trotter special, and Hereford and trotter dish. To be honest, I've had better marrow bones in the states, but this would be a close second. Very good, just different flavors which I think are at a disadvantage compared to some others I've had. My love had the pigeon and trotter special which she enjoyed very much. I had the Hereford and trotter dish which was also delicious. Two things about that though - the crispy pig skin they prepared was basically inedible, and the cut of meat was probably too undercooked for many, but I found it enjoyable. I would make this a required stop when visiting.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Hereford pork roast and pigeon special
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Marrow bones

9tc_Idw2kLwcrPIhNhqQsw.text: We received a warm greeting from the host, who invited us to grab a drink at the bar, since we were early. Again, good service there. It's a nice airy space that is not too crowded. Things were off to a good start. We were then seated at our table in the dining room--a cool, extra-wide table for two, so we didn't feel too smashed in. The place was busy and things were hopping. But it was all sorta downhill from there. The service was really abysmal. No warmth. Which is okay if it's efficient. Which it wasn't. Lots of staring at dirty plates. No one asking whether things were okay. Waiting for the dessert menu. Waiting for the waitress to come back for the dessert order (which we finally decided to skip, so poor was the service). Waiting for the bill as we watched her chatting with the other waiters or clearing other empty tables. And then waiting again for her to return so that we could pay and get the hell outta there (we finally had to physically get up and flag her down). The type of service that drives a diner nuts, really. The food: bone marrow was fine--tasted like bone marrow you'd get anywhere...I have not idea why this is considered a signature dish. The herring was great. The eel was also good. The deep fried tripe was truly awful. Final note: the lavatories were filthy. Water and bits of soggy paper on the floor, grimy tile, dirty doors...plain old gross. Details, guys, details. You can do better than this.

0nLozz2ajBiCLdUQAU41xA.text: If you're curious about offal and true british food, come here first. However, if you're looking for a Michelin experience, try someplace else.Pig Spleen wrapped in bacon. Now, I hadn't had pig spleen before this, but slate grey liver-like coils of spleen, and thick tender fat, cut with reduced vinegar, cornichon and onion? Yes I will savor 3-4 tiny bites of that please.Pig ear salad had a wonderful secret darkness to it. Five spice? Just the nature of pig skin? hard to say, but marvelously cut with cucumbers and parsley.Faggots were my least favorite of the dishes. The waiter was being both patronizing and irresponsible when he said "they're like meatballs." When a ball of meat is made with lamb liver and pork fat, the likeness is fleeting. I liked the offal-rich flavor, but they were very heavy and dense. While the braised onions and firm lentils went well as a homey stew, none of the dish was elevating.The Bath Chaps are my recommended order. First, think of pork belly. Where sometimes the meat layers in pork belly are a little stringy or tough or crunchy (it's bacon, after all), make that meat meltingly, braisedly tender. Now the fat. Crisp the fat gently, just on the edges, like the brown tip of fat on the edge of a nicely seared steak. That is bath chaps. Put that next to a fresh dandelion salad, not bitter or stringy but young and springy, in a dressing celebrating English mustard and olive oil.For dessert, we had the cherry and custard tart. The texture was amazing - crust was replaced with the thinnest layer of cake, and the top was toasted. The custard was sweet and smooth. The problem was that the cooked cherries were so tart and the custard so sweet, that even mixing the two in my mouth didn't create balance. The few cherries I had that were ripe tasted bland, so it didn't seem like they were purposefully going for a tart and sweet thing or a sweet and sweet thing; it seemed like they hadn't checked their produce. Oh, and for 8.50 a slice, you can buy a cherry pitter and a stage to operate it.But here's the thing. I don't generally change ratings based on service, but this place has a Michelin star. It's not just that the waiter was careless. It was the paper tablecloths, the same metal breadbaskets as the neighborhood curry house. Heavy short wineglasses and mediocre, metallic St John's branded wines to go in them. The bread? Not great. Sort of a normal country loaf with a too-soft crust, and I found the brown one too sweet. I know Michelin isn't supposed to be about service, but some of these features actively detracted from the food.

H7GhdXhmTcotLeM5MIJaLg.text: Best English food I've had in London this time around.  Tried the calf liver with dandelion, shrimp salad, side greens, and the turbot.  The lamb/dandelion and the side greens were the stand-outs to me.  The bitterness of the dandelion was balanced perfectly by the richness of the liver (though it was liver of the more meaty variety).  And the side greens were naturally spicy, with a light dressing.

upyaeDZhWjiOtpCSCZAoow.text: Yes, I'll admit it. Anthony Bourdain is the reason we had to eat at St. John. My hubby is a big fan, and since we were going to be in London for a few days on our way to Scotland, I promptly made a reservation. We really enjoyed this place. For how famous it seems to be it was not at all pretentious; the décor is simple and clean. I could imagine living in the neighborhood and having dinner here frequently (a girl can dream!). My husband was very much hoping to try the bone marrow, so we were a little bummed that it wasn't on the menu that day. Note, this is a "Nose to Tail" place, which basically means utilizing all parts of the animal, so you may encounter some very interesting and unique dishes. We both went with meat heavy plates: Corned beef for me, which came with spinach. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned. The presentation is not fancy; it is all about the food at this place. This is the first (and only) Michelin-starred restaurant that I have been to. It did not disappoint. And we didn't feel as if we spent a fortune to eat there, which was surprising, because we also had wine and dessert! Will definitely become a regular haunt the moment we are able to purchase ourselves a flat in London. Fingers (and tails) crossed!

NHO7m7JxpTD2JZpJ93SbRA.text: This meal was fine. I don't think it's a must-visit place, despite what Bourdain may claim. I called asking for a reservation and was told that 10:15pm was the next available time slot. We showed up at 10 to find the place half empty. Kinda weird but whatever. we ordered 3 apps (shrimp salad, roe on toast, and some fancy greens dish) and 2 mains (lamb tongue and hare). It was all interesting but not anything I'd crave again. Server was nice enough and ambiance was simple, a bit spartan even. Can't say I'd recommend this place to friends. I'm sure there are better offal places elsewhere.

AWY7Nqgr6kmE5IClafNbTA.text: Order the roast bone marrow if they have it. Thank me later.Meat lovers have a lot to experience here. No matter what part of an animal you want - or think you want - they've got it, and the staff can make recommendations should their visceral vocabulary twist you around. Last I was here we had a variety of items, all prepared expertly. Their menu changes daily, so my recommendations probably wouldn't be that useful...Find St. John's a short walk from Farrington station.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. View from the sidewalk

B9Bl8vY5NbU28qGetdOH1A.text: Mouthwatering delicious and a pretty reasonable value.  I got the bone marrow, potted beef, and buttered asparagus and they were all delicious.  The acidity and freshness of the  parsley salad offsets the fattiness of the bone marrow perfectly. The potted beef with pickled walnuts and green beans was equally delicious and as simple as the buttered asparagus was, it was also lovely.I hesitated before coming here because of how simply (and perhaps not very inspiringly) some of the items are plated, but the food speaks for itself.Total cost was £28.50 for the three dishes.  Worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Asparagus with warm butter
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Potted beef with green beans and pickled walnuts
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Roasted bone marrow with parsley salad

1vUgnum5fcrNUAGcJWLTyA.text: A must stop for any London foodie.   Expect simple plating, rich, satisfying food, and a casual atmosphere.  I feel like this place is OG hipster.Bone marrow is punchy and wonderful.  The salt, parsley, and bone marrow go together so well.Welsh rarebit is a must, as are the fresh baked Madelines for dessert.If you can, grab some amazing doughnuts from the bakery to go!  Apparently Fergus is often around too if you can spot him.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bread and butter pudding
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow = best dish
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Fresh baked Madelines

iBpXZmJcTC0n-VHztYQhTQ.text: I came here based on the recommendation of a business associate that swore her taste buds on the food here.  Maybe I was just not use to this style of food? Very friendly service and cute little restaurant.

Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

MVV4y7A91OoUdE_XdRj9Wg.text: Incredible restaurant that deserves the high praise from critics and regular diners alike. It wasn't as hard as I thought it would be to get a reservation and table. In fact, for a party of 3, they were nice enough to seat 2 of us first even when our 3rd didn't arrive for another hour after the reservation -- that's service (plus the actual dinner service was on point, friendly, and efficient).The food itself isn't served fancifully or in any exquisite setting. However, it all comes across as more focused on the food and just having a good time with your companions. The pork terrine was excellent as a starter. The artichokes were also fantastic starters.The middle white pork main was incrediblye tender and flavorful. The vegetable and potato sides were served very simply/basic but were the perfect accompaniments to the entrees. The wine menu here was very reasonably priced and all great French wines. I'd come back here in a heartbeat.

kOiJEZu2W-A9bAdkkMvRpw.text: St John is a restaurant that has a very clear idea of who it is. This allows it to make some bold choices about how it presents itself. I find that interesting because although there are plenty of places to buy good food in London, the words 'fine dining' usually demand a certain sheen to the proceedings. A sheen that can occasionally be used to distract attention from, say, mediocre food. St John's very sparseness means that the food and the service have nowhere to hide. You can't be sidelined by the acres of challenging art on the walls - because there isn't any - and the only concession to design is an almost unbroken line of coatpegs running around the walls at just above head height. It reminds me a little of a classroom in a minor public school. This is not, contrary to what you may think, a bad thing, partly because the confection of scent that that conjurs up in my head  a faint whiff of old cabbage and gym socks  fails to materialise and you're left with the perfume of really good cooking. When I say that there's no sheen to St John, I don't want you to think that it isn't slick. Front of house is friendly and brutally efficient, as was our waitress. Perhaps too efficient, almost: I don't doubt that she's answered questions about the specifics of the menu more times than I've eaten er pigs chitterlings, but that's no excuse for blitzing through it like Lewis Hamilton through a crash barrier. The menu, in case you're wondering, is as sparse as the decor. There's no attempt to explain the ins and outs of the aforementioned chitterlings, or indeed the Ox Heart with Chips, or any of the other oddball concoctions. As I'd imagine most of the clientele will feel faintly apprehensive about precisely what they're getting, explanation would seem to me to be absolutely de rigeur. I started gently, with brown shrimp and white cabbage in a herby, crème fraiche-y sort of dressing. It was lovely without being spectacular: a refreshing, almost palate-cleansing intro. My partner charged straight in with sliced saddle of venison accompanied by a celeriac and horseradish splurge. The venison was absolutely thrilling: sweet, soft, rich and compelling. Almost the high point of the meal. Almost. My partner's main was a couple of slabs of Gloucester Old Spot pork, smoked and pot roasted with marrow and potatoes. Lovely, but almost too easy for a place like this. Let's be honest, roast pork is great but it's not a culinary journey into the unknown. Which made me terribly glad that I'd chosen ox heart. Sliced into thin strips and pan fried, with excellent crispy chips in attendance, it was a dark and dangerous plateful of meaty joy. I really, really cannot recommend it highly enough. The wine list veered into the overly expensive, but there were plenty of reasonably bottles for under £35 and a youngish burgundy served to wash all this goodness down. After the mains, desserts were almost comic in their simplicity. My strawberry sorbet with a shot of ice-cold vodka freshened me up nicely, while figs in honey with a crème fraiche accompaniment was lovely and comforting but very rich after all that meat. St John is probably not for everyone, although the packed dining room on Friday night seemed to say otherwise. It's also not cheap, with dinner for two (including a £35 bottle of wine) coming in at over £100 with tip. Still, it's an experience you'll find in few other places. My advice is to go, bury any misgivings you have, and choose something you're really not too sure about. If you like meat, I give you a 90% chance you'll love what you're given.

U1XGBL5DJfQMkeX-Kmls8Q.text: A great place. Excellent British cuisine with desert to go with it. Service is a bit uppity and borderline "you are lucky I'm serving you" but if you can get past that then you are in for a real quality experience in the food and ambience.

p3qC_YHxJaPTAu1qu3CYPQ.text: This is such a cracking restaurant. Seasonal, English/British food prepared in simple and often traditional, yet exquisite ways. It's a fairly fashionable restaurant, yet it's one of the few such where you don't look at the menu and wonder whether the chef is playing ingredient bingo. I've had some fantastic pork in here, puffball mushrooms, tripe - things I either wouldn't normally encounter, or wouldn't necessarily choose if I did - the point is, you can trust the fact that everything that comes out of the kitchen here is going to be great, so you can afford to be a bit adventurous. The wine list is great, as is the service, and the whole thing is offset nicely by the very simple decor.

cv7YUIBTcQDN2hDFyybNgg.text: Excellent new British food in a comfortable setting.  At St. John the food is first and foremost and they make no bonses about it.  The casual setting belies the seriousness in the kitchen.The marrow appetizer was sensational.  I love marrow bones and these delivered.  Plus they had the appropriate spoon to get every last bit of marrow from the warm bones.  The parsley salad was a nice accompaniment to the toast and marrow.Duck hearts were good but not something I'd order myself.  Very meaty.Pigeon was served on the rare side with the head and rib cage removed.  The meat was a bit gamey, a good thing.Welsh rarebit with worcestershire sauce was very rich as a side dish, perhaps we should have gotten it as a pre dessert.Warm madelienes straight from the oven are worth the 15 minute wait.I would have eaten at St. John a second time during my trip, had my schedule permitted.

3SJAHcuk5H6T-FlD3dGYtA.text: I still dream about their grilled razor clams. Sometimes, the dreams are laced with the bone marrow delight they served (can't remember the exact name). If this is traditional British food, please can I have more?

S_qX6ANBQJZdunf3qUn70w.text: One of my friends raved about this place so this was the only place in London I made a reservation for when I visited this spring. I had just arrived earlier that day from Paris where I ate extremely well, so my expectations were quite high. I got the black squid ink appetizer and the grilled pigeon as a main. The squid was good - it was served room temperature and the portion was quite large, and had pickled onions that complemented the squid, but I've had squid + ink served better and more creatively elsewhere. The pigeon was poor - I ordered it pink but it was still too dense and done for my taste. Also, I felt like the preparation was too simple - it didn't taste like anything; I'm not even sure if they bothered to salt and pepper it before grilling, and it didn't taste of being grilled. The skin was not crispy, I didn't see any value in its preparation. The service was quite good though (very attentive and polite), especially on a Friday night. The location and space is pretty neat, though the setup is a bit confusing with the tables out front and in the atrium, but the actual restaurant up the stairs from the bar.

g8LdxTGoGVXR6HVZ36Cm3g.text: If there is one place to eat in London it is most definitely St John's.  Fergus Henderson is a genius and St John's is his masterpiece.A completely casual setting were you can see bikers mingle with business men over their shared carnivorous delights.  Come prepared to enjoy dishes that consist of items such as bone marrow, ox heart, back fat, and fried pig tails.  And guess what?  It is all beyond delicious!!I know many of the faint of heart will back away from St John saying it is cruel and unusual.  But I tend to agree with the Fergus philosophy ... if you are going to kill something, EAT ALL OF IT!Make a reservation well in advance because it fills up.  If you can't get a reservation you can still get into the bar and eat there.  The menu is different (and some courses are actually better).

GMJdeFaBrbhUvxNdxr_tmg.text: One of my favorite places in London. I came here with my mom last September and we shared a few dishes. She particularly enjoyed the bone marrow appetizer and both of us loved the desserts. Great beer and wine selection as well. The service was great! Our waitress was very knowledgable and accommodating. I will come back next time I am in London.

fSD4mBzYinV4PlIbVeKdbw.text: This was an extraordinary meal.  When my wife and I arrived in London a few weeks ago, jet lagged and dazzled by the jazzy check-in at the nearby W Hotel, we were in need of something wonderful, and here we decidedly found it.  I am not a terribly adventurous diner, but I found myself eating pig cheeks and snails to begin (without all the French restaurant garlic usually drowning out their inner snail selves) and lamb "faggots" which I learned involved the heart and such.  What an eye opener, what a revelation.  Our mustachioed server was a font of information and charm.  My wife had the pork chop, which was just fab (though I ribbed her for her tame choice).   My one disappointment was my inability to put a name to the pretty familiar face of the man having dinner with Ralph Fiennes, across the room.

wsedBjpsgBs8goExCRET3w.text: It's not much to look at, but you shouldn't be concentrating on the decor. St. John is an absolute feast - from the famous bone marrow salad to the cockles starter or the lovely pigeon. My only issue was that I ate too much when I was there! I should have listened to our server who raised an eyebrow at how much food my dining partner and I ordered. Rightly so. Food coma, indeed.

5B1Rf_GZ7QLXRiPTQ3PpTQ.text: Amazing. I came her in June 2013 for a birthday dinner with my boyfriend. We started with the bone marrow and parsley salad, and we sopped up every last bit with the toast. I had the calf liver and onions as my main, which was wonderfully rich and melted in my mouth. My boyfriend ordered kid faggots and we also got a side of Welsh rarebit, all of which were exceedingly tasty. The atmosphere of the restaurant was simple but sophisticated, and the service was impeccable. I loved every bit of this restaurant.

KlJuNJntuMNg4cJm82DksQ.text: When I'm back in London, St. John is a must. You might say it's "offaly good". And the anchovy toast in the bar is the business.Simply put, classic is every way.

2zD1X43fl_cxjx4hLljcCA.text: Everything we ate here (roast bone marrow and parsley salad, braised hare and mash, lemon sole, side of greens and apple crumble) was tasty and the service was good but this restaurant just left me feeling cold. They may use the whole of the animal but they forgot the soul.

VYu0dt6TgoxGO_IdyYGJUA.text: Took a friend here recently. It's awesome. Great atmosphere, cool location, handy to the City. Most importantly, brilliant food.

3fTn9lMp0qcvILpew9vcDg.text: Utterly delicious and, when it opened, unique to have so much offal.  Very good bar snacks too.

fVsRHGS0XbvaH8wDNEdR6Q.text: This restaurant turned to be my favourite, since I first came here, recommend it highly!

bgZU5wE0R526AMJKkughxQ.text: So many people come here and now I know they do for a pretty good reason, recommend it strongly!

QyNT6IVbzM6ijZrSoabZtw.text: During our recent trip to London, my wife and I were lucky enough to follow a friend's recommendation and dine at St. John.  This is not a touristy place by any means but a true culinary WOW in a casual, local environment.  If you love food, hate the 'usual suspects' and want to eat where locals do then you must try St. John!

E3qy1FQ2VLpYipSNhxKRVg.text: St John's is an institution. Known around the world for Fergus Henderson's championing of nose to tail eating - if you are a visitor to London it is really the place you must eat at. A warning though, if you are vegetarian don't bother. The thing about nose to tail eating is that you are going to end up eating a lot of meat - in particular offal. Don't worry though if you don't think too much about what you are eating it will be delicious. For a special treat if you get 18 of your closest friends together you can pre order a whole suckling pig for your table. It is £320 for the whole pig which is not cheap but split between 18 it is not too bad and what an amazing experience. Highly recommend.

zC6-20sqy0m9w1kg47zaqA.text: I knew this restaurant from blog, seems it is difference from others British restaurant .my husband like its ox heart , but my favorite is bone marrow.a little bit sad about roast middle white.dessert is also good.can book from its website，but must provide credit card guarantee，if no show ， will deduct 15p every person

cOD92CYXBO--OkhrqwBiNg.text: My husband was on a constant loop talking about St John prior to our trip to London. I don't think I have ever seen him as excited about a dinner as he was for this one.The interior of the restaurant is basic. Just white walls,white tables and no need for fancy decorations. The food is definitely the star of the show.The menu changes, but a constant seems to be the bone marrow, which my husband thinks is the greatest food on Earth. He enjoyed every single bit of his dish!We shared the greens, perfect to go with some of the heavier dishes, and the welsh rarebit. Oh gosh. So good. I also enjoyed my less adventurous dishes. They definitely do their food well.The only reason I didn't give 5 stars was because of service. The couple next to us were seated after us and given a wonderful run down of the menu, some of the dishes they recommended and a really nice discussion about the restaurant with the server. We received none of that. We barely even spoke to our servers. I wish my husband would have had their experience to really have made the evening perfect.

n12A2Qd5Q3UYTXZnNQyPkg.text: We had a very good and very interesting (to us) dinner here. This is not usually our favorite type of food, but we went in with a very open mind and were pretty happy with the result.After a lot of deliberation, we got the crispy pig skin, the Welsh rarebit, the beetroot, the roast bone marrow, and the roast tamworth, followed by a half dozen madeleines, a lemon tart, and a scoop of mint ice cream. Our favorite was probably the Welsh rarebit -- we had no idea what it was coming in, but we were sold when we found out it was essentially like a cheesy bread / grilled cheese, and this was among the best versions of that I can remember eating. The bone marrow was also great, in exactly the way you'd expect. We enjoyed the tamworth and the lentils that came with it as well, but I didn't think it was overly memorable. Same for the beetroot.The madeleines are much-hypes, and deservedly so. We liked all three desserts, but this was the obvious standout.Overall, really solid food, and a good excuse for us to branch out a bit. I wouldn't have it as one of the top 100 places in the world, but I'm really glad we went regardless.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Welsh rarebit
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Dinner menu (8/22/2018)
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bread

jgudOn7aa6FbziemUx1DgQ.text: Both the late great Anthony Bourdain and Andrew Zimmerman showcased this place so of course I had to check it out. Very white and bright minimalistic interior decor. This is a true nose to tail place, If you want burgers or steaks this is not the place for you, if you culinary tastes are more adventurous then you need to come here.Their most famous famous dish is the bone marrow with parsley salad. Such decadent marrow that you push out of large bone and spread atop crusty bread and top with some tangy parsley salad. Oh so good.We also tried the braised rabbit and escargot and sausage soup. All were such a tasty delight.The staff were great, the beer was cold and the atmosphere was warm. This is a must go for all foodies out there!

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Escargot and sausage soup
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Braised Rabbit
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow and parsley salad

dZr0qgDiv32jWiTFo3XOmA.text: So many good things to say about this place. Completing our holiday in Europe, it was one of our last meals and we both decided that this was meal was fantastic and the service was so good. Atmosphere was great. I liked the simplicity and how it matched the whole building with the bar and entry, etc. Our waitress was on-point. She was super helpful, communicative, had good recommendations, and read us so well in the sense that she wasn't hovering over us or rushing us or not existent. Ha, overall just great service. That being said, the food, oh man, it was so good. Being a nose to tail restaurant we weren't s quite sure what to expect but we knew that the bone marrow was a must as it is a dish that is always on the menu even while other dishes change. Our menu choices: Mussels and White Cabbage SaladCrispy Pig Skin and DandelionRoast Bone Marrow and Parsley SaladRoast Middle White, Fennel, and Trotter Green SaladStrawberry Eton MessSuch a scrumptious meal for sure. Their specials sounded really good too. While it was our first time in London, it seemed like it may be homey British comfort food. While the ingredients seemed simple, the depth and flavor was so good and went so well together. The ingredients were very fresh as well. The two salads that we had (mussels and crispy pig skin), were really great choices for us. The mussels were I believe the best mussels I've ever had and the crispy pig skin was so fresh and stayed crunchy while eating the meal and complemented the dandelion well. Roast Bone Marrow, oh soo good!  Complete the bite with the marrow, a bit of parsley and onion, and salt, yum! Roast Middle White, Fennel and Trotter, comfort food and flavorful.Green salad: simple flavors but fresh and pallatte cleansing between the dishes, bigger than we expected but went well with our meal.Strawberry Eton Mess: yummy strawberries with cream, meringue, puree, etc. Not overly sweet and the strawberries and meringue chunks were pleasant. Went well with our espressos! We wanted to try many things but of course couldn't order everything. We will have to return another time... :P Tip: Make reservationsTip2: You have to walk through the bar before you get to the dining room which is on your right up a few stairsTip3: No phone signage as courtesy which was great so you don't get people on their screens the whole meal and instagramming or facebooking everything. That being said, I did have my actual camera and did take pictures of the food.  Tip4: Wine recommendations were great!

t4RCm0Vje8gI_OPINMj5bg.text: Definitely know ahead of time what type of food you are going to be eating. I wanted to try a different type of British cuisine and saw this restaurant kept popping up in all the lists but it just wasn't for us. Food was very very rich and hard for my stomach to process during and after the meal. Menu changes daily so also hard to plan ahead but we had the bone marrow (3/5), cod appetizer (4/5 - the best part was the lentils), cured beef with horseradish (5/5) and kidneys on toast (1/5 - just not for us and too much of it). Wine list was average. Service was friendly. Just wasn't for us

hw50nlDQmBMgAH9Ixu0XGA.text: The airy yet austere dining hall welcomes you to a realm where the food is the star.  I had mussels cooked with leeks and cider as a starter.  The mussels were cooked beautifully and despite the base being comprised of such light fare like leeks and cider, the broth had a lot of depth to it.  Definitely my favorite part of the meal.  You will not be served a shellfish fork so the server suggested I use one of the discarded shells to wrangle the mussel out, which worked marvelously. For my main course I had smoked Scottish haddock in a heavy cream sauce with garlicky mashed potatoes.  Definitely very heavy and one has to be very adept to remove bones along the course of the meal but the efforts pay off.  There was a definite smokiness to the fish that was scooped up by the creaminess of the heavy cream.  Both smoky and creamy flavors emboldened the modest mashed potatoes and made it part of the team instead of an entity on the side lines.  My only regret, besides the presentation, was that over time, the flavors that were once so daring became muted and almost one-noted towards the end of the meal.The fresh mint tea I had to cap off the meal steeped for about 10 minutes but was still very light.I definitely recommend to go to this establishment if you are feeling adventuresome and have the time to delve into interesting taste profiles.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Muscles cooked with leeks and cider.
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Smoked Scottish haddock in a heavy cream sauce with garlicky mashed potatoes.

0mQCoii4raOT19WxrMzxWQ.text: We went here because we wanted to try bone marrow, and after it came up in a search, we realized their bone marrow dish was Anthony Bourdain's death row meal. So, that was a clincher. You need a reservation. But we made ours the day before, we checked on Thursday for a Friday time and it was easy on OpenTable! They will hold a card and charge if you cancel. The restaurant is inside (not in the garage/foyer), near the bar inside (well lit), but up the stairs to the right. It took us a few minutes to figure out where we were supposed to go. St. John has 5 "No" policies. No music, no art, no garnishes, no service tax and no flowers. I personally loved this, though I couldn't put my finger on what I liked until after our meal. The walls are a soft buttery white, coat hooks adorn the room above all perimeter tables and the table scape is white. The sound is conversation and kitchen noises. It felt like you were in a large living room, because there wasn't any piped in classical music or smooth jazz. Our waiter was so great, and I'm thankful we had someone to guide us through the process of this place. We knew we wanted the marrow salad. He recommended a nice red wine for me to go with the marrow, it was a chianti of some kind. He didn't hover or check in too much, it was a subtle art of service and he had it nailed. He asked if we wanted anything besides the marrow to start, and we asked if the marrow was pretty filling. He said it was. After our salad arrived, he gave us a crash course in how to use the lobster pick and the sage advice, "Don't be afraid to get messy!" Thank God I know Cole pretty well already, because we got messy. As he cleared away our plates, we honestly thought of canceling our mains, because the marrow was so filling. We came really close to flagging him down and saying we'd just do appetizers and dessert. But we let the mains come.We both had the middle white (a special kind of pig) with parsnips and a mustard gravy sauce. I never knew I liked parsnips. I don't usually eat pork, but honestly, this was the meltiest, most perfect pork I've had in my life. I didn't think anything could be better than the marrow on toast but the pork should really be considered! I am so so so glad we didn't cancel them. When we return, we'd probably split a marrow salad. They serve it with 3 large bones. However, the dinner portions weren't so large as to be overwhelming. In fact, we left room for dessert. Letting the waiter guide us through the dessert options was fun, and we ended up settling on the cherry trifle. It was a chocolate pudding layered with cherries and topped with whipped cream. Def too large to have alone but perfect to share. The perfect cap to a perfect meal! The meal took about 90 mins, so allow ample time to savor. We left satisfied and happy but not stuffed to the gills.

y3CTEbrLeOoEMipi542Lzw.text: Learned about this place from one of Anthony Bourdain's shows. Made dinner reservations for this place 3 weeks before traveling to London.They change their menu often, but one constant is the BONE MARROW. We ordered a few dishes, but we probably could have done without them and ordered only the bone marrow. Omg it was so good.. so rich and packed with umami flavor. We ended with fresh Madeleine cookies that were amazing as well. There's a bar attached to the restaurant where you can order food (including the bone marrow). If you're a small party (2 to maybe 4 people) and you don't have a res, it's worth trying to snag bar seats and ordering there. In fact, if I am lucky enough to ever come back, I'll prob opt to eat at the bar area instead.

iudwsgwGNPTjgxTLQ3filg.text: After watching The Meat Show episode featuring St. John, the bone marrow and parsley salad here skyrocketed to the top of my London foodie list. Even after all the hype, the restaurant's signature dish did not disappoint. Every bite is an explosion of well-balanced flavors and textures: the fattiness of the marrow, the crunch of the bread, the acidity of the salad. I'd also recommend trying the Welsh rarebit, but only if you are into intense cheeses. It has a strong flavor profile and is more of an acquired taste.

44pXvuyLZmiW0uu3-q2uaA.text: Hands down one of my absolute favorite restaurants anywhere, ever. As they note on their website, it's head to tail, with purpose and simplicity. Food: Order the bone marrow. It's divine. Veal marrowbones, served with grilled day old sourdough bread made at their bakery, and a parsley salad made with parsley, shallots, and capers dressed with olive oil and lemon juice and seasoned with sea salt and pepper. It's served with coarse, "wet" grey sea salt to dress the marrow with. I like to dive into the marrow with the lobster pick provided, slather it over the bread, sprinkle with sea salt, and top with the parsley salad. Savor every bite. This is definitely shareable, but we usually don't :-) Always hear out the daily specials, as they are usually worth trying. The only thing we tend to order off the menu is the bone marrow. Service: Efficient, knowledgeable staff, that are reasonably attentive. Cost: Two bone marrows, two mains, one green, two glasses of wine, and one desert ran about £106. Quite worth the money. Overall: Do make a reservation. It's almost impossible to be seated otherwise. There are other St. John restaurants, but this is the only one with the one marrow I believe, so keep that in mind when making a booking.

LTsSB0I4bNO5zgsmclEo_Q.text: Had a 2pm resy and a 12:20 landing at Heathrow. Hit some glitches and didn't make it there till 2:45 (which is their last seating for lunch). Luckily I had called ahead and they were quite accommodating.Got the Welsh Rarebit to start, which was absolutely delicious, and even better with the Worcestershire sauce... but then game the Bone Marrow... My word!Possibly some of the best bone marrow I've ever had.I sincerely apologize for only noticing the 'no cell phone' sign *after* the meal.

dsCYBG9dHxJ8RnAgJ_Ybtg.text: I have long been a fan of Fergus Henderson (thank you Bourdain!) and his nose to tail cooking.  On my visit to London I wanted to ensure I stopped in for a meal at St. John.Given that the menu doesn't really change that much from day to day, I decided to book a table for a 2 pm Sunday lunch/brunch.  I ordered the bone marrow to start, and had the sea bass with braised fennel for my entree.  I glass of rose and some slices of their bread accompanied my meal.  The main thing I appreciated about my meal was that each dish was so simply prepared, yet prepared so well!  They let the ingredients speak for themselves and shine.  The bone marrow came in four pieces of bone, with a salad of capers, parsley, shallots, lemon, sea salt, and two slices of their grilled bread.  I thought the dish was delicious but felt it was better if I had shared this dish.  The marrow is quite rich and two "bones" would have been more than enough.  The salad and salt provided such a great contrast to the richness of the marrow.As for the fish, this had to be one of the best preparations of sea bass I have had.  The skin was crisp and the fish was cooked to absolute perfection.  It was flaky and very fresh.  Although I don't generally enjoy fennel their preparation allowed for the sharpness of the anise flavor to be dampened a bit.  There was a very light sauce with this dish but it did not overwhelm or mask the flavors of the fish at all.Unfortunately I had no room for dessert!  As much as the mind was willing, the stomach was full.My waiter could not have been nicer or more engaging and friendly.  He patiently answered my questions and asked me about my visit, once he found out I was not a local.  He helped complete the wonderful meal I experienced here.  The restaurant was fairly easy to find from the Farringdon station.  Reservations are recommended.  While it wasn't difficult to book a spot (Opentable) all tables were filled during my visit.  There is also the option to enjoy a lighter meal and their wines in the bar downstairs.

uAmnr-C7cDdvORNORWtUvA.text: For most of the world outside of London, St. John and its Chef Fergus Henderson probably burst into our collective consciousness when some guy called Tony Bourdain (on the London episode of his first show, A Cook's Tour) engaged with Chef Fergus Henderson on what may have been the first US televised treatise on "Nose to Tail Eating" (also the title of Fergus' groundbreaking cookbook). It captured one of the earliest moments of this era in which food has attained elevated cultural stature alongside art, music, and theater. Almost two decades later - where almost all restaurant cooking associates itself with  some form of regional cuisine, and the provenance of ingredients can almost be presumed - how does St. John remain relevant?  This place just has a knack for preparations that never try to do too much with the ingredient, while ensuring that you'd have no regrets if it were to be done this way forever.Starters involved: mandoline-sliced Kohlrabi (cabbage bred with an over-emphasis on its stubby root) dressed lightly in lemon and oil, with tiny capers and even tinier leaves of parsley. A plate of Smoked Sprats (a kissing cousin of sardines, herring and anchovy) that, if you closed your eyes, has that same smoky tang of a frankfurter hot dog.  We also couldn't resist the prospect of a plate of cold roast mutton/chicory/anchovy spotted on the Bar menu on the way in.  It turned out to be a re-imagination of a Caesar salad - leaves of endive, sliced shallots, and roast mutton (not gamey at all) tossed in an anchovy dressing that makes no apologies for containing anchovy.Next course in, crusty (previously crispy) lamb sweetbreads are enveloped in a stew of spring - a juxtaposition of lush spring peas and long cooking with salted pork (and an exemplary specimen of that timeless technique of smothering the crispy/crusty in a dense sauce, while somehow coming out with a net positive). The garnish of raw pea sprouts may have been a bit superfluous, but one must nonetheless appreciate the conceptual flourish in this English rendition of alla Primavera.A vegetarian main of Artichokes, Broad Beans (Favas) and Goat Curd - a runner-up as dish most redolent of springtime  during this meal- served as a hefty side.Pigeon roasted medium rare -two halves taken off the bone- without even a hint of the livery-ness typical of this domesticated gamebird.  While lamenting a lack of sauce and a very slight dryness from this well hung bird, I'm certain we committed some sort of taboo by reaching for the salt and pepper grinders.  We were more than halfway through before we realized the half of an endive caramelized in butter on the side must have been intended to contribute the requisite lubrication and condiment.As we tucked into our aforementioned mains, the regret of not ordering the Hake haunted us (a rare treat for those from outside of the North Atlantic, the unofficial national fish of Spain). So we put in an extra order, a bone-in tranche cut close to the fish's tail. Lightly starched and crisped, it was as if this fish campaigning for itself as the superior alternative to Cod and Haddock for frying.   The purple sprouting broccoli -dressed in a mayonnaise-ey concoction involving sliced shallots and capers and some red spicing (paprika?)- does the work you might expect from a tartare sauce. For the denouement, we opted for after-dinner savouries instead of sweets.  An all British cheese plate notable for its deliciousness (I presume by now you're as tired of my descriptions as my palate was tired by the end of the meal- so please just refer to pics).I would also be remiss if I did not give a mention to the wines.  The list leaning heavily towards Southern France, offers a number of St. John's proprietary bottlings, including those from their own Boulevard Napoleon winery in Minervois.  We tried a few of these available by the glass, all are straightforward wines that pair well with the rustic and flavorful food, while never becoming a distraction. P.S.For those of lamenting the lack of photos, I apologize for this negligence (with the exception of one snap of the cheese course).  My wife -who is usually responsible for capturing such moments in a visual medium- was very much occupied:  the 2 of us were busy gorging ourselves on this meal which, according to the menu, should feed 4.

PYbVoevCz2PYRUErx0W-3g.text: For those of you familiar with Barry Levinson's movie Diner, there is a scene where a patron walks into the titular establishment and proceeds to order the left-hand of the menu while others look on in wonder. The reason I mention this comedy is that our party of eight attempted a similar feat when at St. John, except that we set our sights on the entire menu. We did not quite check off the box next to each & every item, but I think I filled in my organ meat quota for the next year, or ten years.Service is top-notch, and the atmosphere is warm and inviting while not too loud to have conversations. I do recommend you come hungry, and even plan your meals leading up the big event accordingly so that you are not faced with the "but I just HAD grilled ox heart for lunch" dilemma.

IzSnib6VOOhSzb6ZMuaAyA.text: I cannot wait to return to London and dine here again. Outstanding flavor, perfect presentation and stellar service. Met and spoke with chef Fegus and although a quirky guy, such a genius. Truly amazing experience.
