yQU8BDCzmVW_0n7KaC3eMA.text: I made the decision to try this place based on Anthony Bourdain's praise of their bone marrow and I am sure glad I gave this place a go. Reservations went relatively quick but I was able to snatch a 9:30 reservation on a Monday. The inside of the restaurant seemed like a factory converted to a restaurant, with white walls, white tables, white everything. The service here was super nice and the smell of the restaurant just screams fresh and delicious.My boyfriend and I tried an assortment of dishes. We started off with the crispy pig cheek, sliced venison and bone marrow. The crispy pig cheek was super crispy and paired wonderfully with dandelion. The venison was moist. The bone marrow was out of this world. I think what made this spectacular for me was just every component this dish came with that further contributed to the flavors of bone marrow. Well-toasted bread with big grains of salt and acidic parsley salad combined with the fatty bone marrow was mind-blowing. So good. A must try.As for the entrees, we decided to be a little more adventurous and tried the grouse. A full small bird that tasted like nothing I have ever eaten before. The texture reminded me of duck but the taste was unique. I honestly cannot fully describe it. The wings were very bitter and the breast was very juicy, also somewhat bloody. It also came with toast spread with grouse pate. That I very much enjoyed. Overall, it was very interesting. I don't think I would personally order it again but it was definitely an experience. We also got the hare which was nice and simple. The meat was tender and cooked perfectly to medium rare.We ended it with their bread pudding with vanilla ice cream and 6 freshly baked madeleines. The perfect end to a very enjoyable meal. The madeleines came fresh out of the oven, super warm and just absolutely amazing. Slightly crisp on the inside, soft yet spongey and moist on the inside. I would go back just to order a dozen more madeleines.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Bread pudding with ice cream
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Freshly baked madeleines

csmqqG6BWZNeiiPXOSUNfQ.text: Where do I begin?! I was honored to have dined at St John seeing as Chef Henderson originated the concept of consuming neglected cuts of meat, one of which is my favorite... bone marrow. My husband, sister and brother in law were able to snag a reservation during our stay in London and boy were we thankful. The decor was refined, the servers were friendly and enthusiastic, the food was delicious. The bone marrow accompanied by the scrumptious parsley salad and toast were perfection, but every other dish was equally as memorable. I had the sea bass as my main course and the skin was crispy, but the meat was flaky and flavorful. Overall, our experience was amazing and I will definitely return on my next visit.

svS_qghmsBU94PA3DMHPlQ.text: I had been dreaming of eating here for years. Finally, a weekend in London, and the opportunity to realize the dream. I feared that my expectations had grown to unreachable heights. They had not.A glass of the St. John 1er cru blanc de blancs at the bar before was excellent. I am usually weary of branded house wines, but the champagne was exceptional. So exceptional that we ordered a bottle of the St John Burgundy (Pinot Noir) with dinner, and were equally pleased. The meal was everything I imagined. Bone marrow is bone marrow, the only thing you can do to muck it up is try to get fancy, which they do not at St John. Toast, salt, parsley salad. Brown shrimp and cabbage was excellent. Asparagus with hot butter was surprisingly exciting considering its simplicity. Crispy pigs ears were one of the greatest dishes I have ever eaten. Crispy, fatty, meaty, balanced by being mixed in a salad of greens and radishes with  alight vinaigrette. Sea bass was perfect. The dish was made by the green sauce.I wish I could have the rarebit every time I drink a little too much. The date cake dessert put us over the top.It was the meal of a lifetime, and we will be flying back from New York again just to eat here. It turned out to be everything everyone ever said it was, and then some.

fskMxDhLbC1S5mSxHBbnoA.text: I've been wanting to visit for years.  It's at the centre of the British food resurgence!  And it was the worth the wait.  It's easy enough to make a reservation via email (deets on the website).  The responses are prompt and polite.  I actually made a mistake and initially made a reservation for the wrong day and the restaurant was so easygoing about switching out the reservation.  They were also rather accommodating when we were 20 minutes late after getting a little lost on the Tube.  The restaurant has a no-frills, yet calm, let's focus on the food, atmosphere.  Stark white, without any wall art, and white table clothes inside, and a little white-painted courtyard outside, the only color comes from the food and drink, and the bustling kitchen that's somewhat open.  On to the food:  the chef was very accommodating of my dairy sensitivity, switching out the buttery greens that normally accompany the calf liver, which was just divine, thinly sliced, meaty and sumptuous, and in my case, served with lovely almost stewed collard greens.  The waiter highly recommended the beef heart with dandelion.  I was a little nervous, as dandelion is one of the very few foods I have never enjoyed, but these ones didn't taste grassy or weed-y at all.  They had been stripped of their outer greens, and marinated for quite some time in a delicious light mustard, that went perfectly with the tender, yet more intense beef heart.  I also quite enjoyed the shrimp and bean (seemingly little brown lentils) and cabbage salad, again nicely dressed, light, and refreshing, yet really flavorful with the little, salty shrimp, perfect for a warmer day with a glass of rose.  The side greens we ordered came with large leafy greens and a pungent, balanced mustard sauce.  It was such a surprise, it almost stole the show.  The only dish I didn't love was the special of the evening, the turbot, but I think it's just that I don't find turbot itself that tender or flavorful.  All in all, it was a truly lovely meal and I'll definitely return the next time I'm in town.

X3-KvTFn-r18EBPlSlOMsA.text: After raving about St. John's Bread and Wine for years, I finally made it to the flagship.  We happened to go on a very cold evening, but somehow managed to survive eating in the bar area.  Now I should warn you that the bar area is not a traditional bar area as I had imagined.  It is kind of like sitting in the warehouse/bakery with high ceilings, the breads coming out of the oven, little wooden tables.  There is a stainless steel bar with some stools so yes, it is a bar.  I love this bar area--my only gripe is that it isn't well heated, so might be a bit better in the summer or on milder winter days.  The bar area has a limited menu--mostly appetizers but lots of them (that are served in the main dining room as well) and some desserts, so you are not missing much by eating there. We enjoyed a delicious cheese plat,e langoustines and some wine and then moved into the main dining room when a table became available.  I was really hoping for a meat dish--there was no beef or lamb on the menu that night.  There was pork loin with parsnips which the boy thoroughly enjoyed and I was not at all disappointed with my snails, sausage and chickpea dish.  YUMMERS!  Service was a bit disappointing and I was a bit disappointed in the menu.  I also hoped it would have something "up" on St. John's Bread and Wine.  I think they are pretty much interchangeable.  All I can say is that you are bound to have a good and unique meal here.

WXhCSNlTrKKKZPdTcb5hRA.text: Fabulous wee-kend in London for Easter Monday. After a glass near the Thames; we went to St. Johnes to eat authentic English cuisine. It's really a great restaurant, take about 30th person. Everything is fresh with flavors that captivate you. 10/10 for the whole.

vpYqyBa7DQk_gcBNJgEyCA.text: Finally!From the moment I learned that Yelp was planning to launch a UK wing, St. John has been at the top of my list of places to visit. Nose to tail is the pitch they present and as a fan of odd and interesting parts of animals and being a devout follower of the Bourdain school of yumminess, how could I not come here?Last night was finally the night. We arrived quite early in the evening and were actually the first ones in the dining room. That's fine with me, I wasn't there for the people, the scene or anything besides the much rumored and foodie adored, Bone Marrow dish. It was the first time I've ever had Marrow de Bone and wow, is there really anything better than smearing fat on toast and then adorning it with thin little slices of red onion and parsley and wet salt. Ummm, no. No there is not.We also ordered the cheese plate and it was divine. Definitely a well plated plate for the pound. (Try saying that 3 times in a row drunk). When it came to picking a main I was at a total loss. Most of the things I had never even heard of. Faggots and Mash, whoa there, you'll get your ass kicked for saying that in the States! Brill, hmm, what is this Brill you speak of? Oh it's fish. But what about this Ox Heart. Ohhhh, the Ox Heart!Our server raved about it, touting it as the best dish and her personal fave on the menu and with a sell like that, how could I go wrong. When it arrived it was beautifully presented and I was ready to dive right in... The first bite: Hmmm, wow, this texture is really different.The second bite: Wow, this is almost kinda spongy or bouncyThe third bite: Steph who friggin uses the terms spongy or bouncy to describe a dish.The fourth bite: Yep, definitely bouncy and definitely deelish.By the end, this was a killer dish and definitely worth going back for! I should also mention that the wine our server recommended was perfect and in a world full of up sells on the menus and servers not really knowing up from down, it was a true joy to come to a place where everything she said was true. Love it.St. John is definitely worth a visit if you are one who doesn't shy away from things out of the norm. It's how I live my life, so I guess that explains the 5 stars :)

A0LGSve6UoKzvftRjeW2ww.text: Here is the only place where they prepare the seafood good enough for me.

m7E3C1IG5HaqnvkhnNZB2g.text: I like this place because it includes a good interior and atmosphere, delicious meals prepared with a lot of effords, good polite attitude that should be appreciated. I like the roasted beef and the coffee ice-cream, but I can not wait to try the twice baked chocolate caked the next time.

WqCj8BRLlaSTQWJ-VM5ANg.text: We've booked a table here last week. The restaurant has a nice atmosphere and friendly and pleasant staff. The food was brilliant on a reasonable prices. My friend liked the place so much that she decided to celebrate her birthday there.

anJh7neDxjCDzZTqpVKQvA.text: This place has received a number of reviews and is supposed to be the one of the originators of snout-to-tail dining.  To be honest, I wasn't really impressed.  We were here for brunch and while I could see the appeal in the menu, it just wasn't very well executed.  There were some simple screw up like serving burnt toast.  Being the gluttons that we are, we also had desert after brunch and again, while good, it didn't impress

wb0N0vlHja97FI941sy77g.text: After hearing much fanfare about Fergus Henderson's legendary nose-to-tail restaurant, we made St John our first stop after our transatlantic flight. Ambiance was very cool. The space was a jigsaw of rooms, each with a rustic feel, as if we had stumbled into a hidden gem. Unfortunately, we found the meal rather underwhelming.Maybe we were just too exhausted from the red-eye, maybe we weren't ordering the right dishes, or maybe, thanks to Fergus Henderson's revolutionary and widespread influence, others have imitated and eclipsed him. We started with the famous roasted marrow and parsley salad--these were quite tasty and indulgent. But, even marrow is a familiar and often well-executed dish on many a menu these days. For mains, we had smoked haddock and pigeon and carrots. The smoked haddock had a nice, smokey flavor but was a little salty., The pigeon was tender but not very exciting. And, definitely not what I had imagined traveling 5,000 miles for. I think we erred in not ordering sweetbreads and other offal. We were looking for a culinary adventure, and we should have ordered one!

-RHPlG6hfbiJFBteuYI8Sw.text: Pretty good place! I gathered my friends there for my birthday party last month. The service was awesome and the interior is great as. The food was served quite slowly but everything else was top notch.

oC8qZY2TSLSLSKzO17bd5w.text: St John is in the meat packing district of London, Smithfield.  Very eclectic menu, lamb tongue, Crispy pigs cheeks and hare saddle!!!! Woot!!! Menu changes frequently, so amazing.  If you're in London give it a try, you won't be disappointed.

34Jlxmh6W7axYggngpr9tQ.text: Excellent sea food, one of the best menues in town. I normally do not eat sea food, but when prepared well, I cannot get enough.This is the case here, great and delicious.

XEFMFAT1br1iUEUMe95EaA.text: I think I must revisit this place now that smoking has been banned.I love the concept, I just don't like snouts and tails, nor do I love or appreciate marrow.  My TH loves this place for all of the above and cold goose.Me, I go to keep  her company and pray that there is something on the menu other than brussel sprout tops, salad and some fish dish. The puddings are good.The bakery is also really good - one of the best christmas puddings I have ever eaten was from there.

m5Fz50cJIdGccata9buJEw.text: Very very good, I would definitely come back here and can see this as a place to become a regular at.  Its like a british tapas place where you order small dishes to share.  High quality, very fresh ingredients.  They were not serving the marrow the day we went so I next time im in london, I'll have to stop by again to try that.  Also, the madelines are great...

JAQ4JPoOuE0gVn9NU8r0zw.text: One of the most memorable meals of my life so far. I ordered the bone marrow toast/salad as a starter and the sweetbreads as a main, neither of which I had tried in my life. The bone marrow was delightfully mellow and buttery and literally melted onto the bread. The waiter was excellent and showed us the proper way to prepare the bread and marrow with a spoonful of rock salt. We were left with our tiny fork things digging at the bones to get the last bit out at the end, and it was difficult to let the waiter take them away. The sweetbreads (for the uninformed, as I was at the time, these are a selection of glands and bits from an animal, usually lamb or calf) were tender and succulent and had the most amazing sauce that I don't have the food vocabulary to describe. We had red wine with our meal, all the wines are French and it was whatever their house option was, and it didn't break the bank while complementing the meal nicely. Every part of this experience was excellent and unforgettable.

xfwq_66OjvdvPfdCUwm-Qw.text: My first meal in London.  Given that I was traveling on some kind of a budget, I decided that I 'd be spoiled enough to have just lunch here.  In my Converse sneakers and a wife beater and black bra straps showing, I made my way in, American accent and all.The bone marrow was so yummy.  At the time it was a solid 5-star in my heart until I tasted bone marrow at Epic in SF (which is much closer to me and a lot cheaper).  But still, the moment I made contact with St John's bone marrow, I was in heaven.  I also got the beet salad with dry pig's liver sprinkled on it.  Those dry bacon textured bits were awesome.  AWESOME.  I sometimes day dream about that unique taste and let out a long, deep sigh.  The lunch did cost me 23 pounds though (2 appetizers and a glass of red wine).  One star deducted for the slightly snooty waitress.

XfkxOM7gHKtIGATjeRDTtA.text: The place for meat eaters and those that love them, St John offers the best of today's market fare, with a new menu daily (handily updated for both lunch and supper on their website).I think the food, if anything, is getting better - I just hope it's not too hard to get in after their first Michelin star. I'm really liking Sunday lunch here: either in the main restaurant, or in the bar, with a selection of small dishes.Standards include bone marrow salad, game birds, Eccles cakes, Madeleines and trifle. The baking and desserts really do excel. There's always a vegetarian option as well, but vegetarians should be prepared for the sight of a lot of meat, including complete sucking pigs, or half a pig's head.Always ask if anything is running out when you sit down: there's a whiteboard in the kitchen listing items that are running low.

erVTvwM3476ovbQPywEHaQ.text: I've never eaten in the main dining room of St. John, but the bar, bar food, and bakery are worthy of five stars on their own.First of all, they make the best welsh rarebit I've ever encountered. It was so rich and cheesy, and the bread was absolutely amazing! Paired with a cold pint and a salad, it was an unbeatable early dinner. The ambiance was awesome too--the super-clean, butcher-esque interior is really fun, and really allows you to focus on having a good time with your friends, rather than being distracted by fussy service or decor.Speaking of the bread in the rarebit, if you live in London, don't bother buying bread anywhere else. Seriously, St. John makes the best sourdough I've had anywhere (including SF California, the home of great American sourdough). The granola is also completely decadent, chock full of dried apricots and vanilla beans! Yum!  If you stop by to buy either of these things, make sure you grab a brownie too. Super chocolatey, super moist--totally worth it (and I don't even like chocolate that much!).

DzIFQGasYu-Bxh41q5SgGQ.text: My girl and I love the seafood here. We are seafood persons and whenever we feel like eating something nice, we come here.

7xnsg1eY0bYQPBld12YvYg.text: The rating should be 4.5 stars. Can I say, go there, go there, go there? I really liked this place. The whole ethos of eating the entire animal and then making it taste so good puts them head and shoulders above everyone. I had a beef heart with just a touch of sea salt, paired with a lighter beer and it was damn near perfect. I've never had beef heart made so simply. Plus I love the white board with the listings of what they have for the night. The downside is that they can run out of things but don't let that dissuade you.Service could be better but when I'm in London I don't tend to worry about that stuff too much...

dhXrqBmtxyNh0mUC5Rm_gQ.text: I really wanted to like St John.  Really, really wanted to like it.  A two Michelin starred restaurant that was incredibly affordable and they served offal to the acclaim of Mr. Bourdain himself?  I marched down to Smithfields for lunch one sunny afternoon and found my companion waiting for me.  Both of us were very much looking forward to our culinary excursion and neither could decide what to get. First thing - the ambiance sucks.  I usually don't mind what the restaurant looks like but for the rating that this place has received I felt as if I had arrived in a slaughterhouse.  The tables and chairs are cheap and uncomfortable as was the service.  When we inquired to a the preparation of a dish we were meet with an arrogance.  I apologize that I have never had spleen before.  We order the following dishes based on the tired recommendations of our server.Starter #1 - Roast Bone Marrow and Parsley Salad - The dish arrived with three bones that were extremely hot to the touch and packed to the top with marrow, bread and the parsley salad.  Now, i am fan of marrow in small portions.  It, like foie gras, really is nothing more than very rich and delectable fat.  So it usually requires something to cut through the grease and elevate the wonderful flavor.  Enter the parsley salad and then watch it jump up and down and destroy any semblance of flavor the marrow might have had.  If this was a boxing match, the marrow would have run out of the ring the second the fight started.  The parsley salad was comprised of parsley(surprise!) capers, sliced onion and a vinaigrette of some sort. When you combine the flavors of the salad, the marrow and the bread together the only thing you can taste is the salad.  Very disappointing!  For all the praise this dish had received I was sorely let down.Starter #2 - Rolled Pigs Spleen with herbs and bacon - This was this the dish we were looking forward to.  The plate arrived with a small bowl filled with a red vinaigrette and pile of sliced onion next to the 4 or 5 slices of spleen.  When the elements of the dish were combined the spleen was incredibly mild and almost undetectable.  If you were to leave on item, say the onion, out the spleen became very potent and almost inedible.  I will restate that I am a fan of offal and order when I can but this was practically eye watering.  Interesting but definitely not great.Main #1 - Lemon Sole with Tartar sauce - this dish a whole lemon sole served with half a lemon and a ramekin of home made tartar sauce.  Mediocre at best.  Not only did the fish taste slightly off but I it was not de-boned nor was an offer of de-boning available.  I am okay with that if I am provided with the correct utensils  to do it myself which of course were not provided or were even available, at least that was what I was told.  Very poor for a restaurant with this rating and reputation.Main #2 - Wood Pigeon - Nothing special at all.  I believe it was roasted had a lovely flavor  but nothing to remarkable about it at all.Recap - Went in with hopes and dreams and left feeling like a Lib Dem supporter from last year.  I just cannot believe that this is ranked in the top 20 restaurants in the world.  Or that this has somehow managed to achieve 2 Michelin stars.  The food was mediocre the service was poor and the ambiance sucks.  The plus side is that the bread was fantastic.  I will give them that.  And only that.

IdQYtjTCfj6_AFNBfdnDsw.text: It's amazing! A must visit. food is amazing, the staff is friendly and the atmosphere is very casual and chill.

gla0iQCGlvBuPugWWtKiTQ.text: I was introduced to the place as a 'head to tail' establishment, meaning all the parts of an animal is used. My impression was that only the parts you normally don't eat was used. A MUST VISIT place for the culinarily curious, but if your diet predominantly is burgers, pizza and pasta....you may not like it. We had bone marrow, duck hearts, a kind of squid dish and (for good measure) a welsh rarebit (some kind of ham & cheese toasty for the non-british). All tremendously delicious!

HX6Au7i-cPcjDh1avrimLg.text: Wonderful clean aesthetic, visionary British cooking. Any true foodie with a decent palate should visit Fergus Henderson's house of meat. The bone marrow and rarebit were life-changing. You can lunch here fairly reasonably, and for all its Michelin baubles, it's worth the trip. Just don't take your picky eater friends. They won't enjoy it.

YBdCP03hBiHT7WA7-tpYmQ.text: Worth the hype. Lots of unique food options, all delicious. Good wines, some decent beers on tap or bottled. It's not a cheap meal but you could order conservatively and it wouldn't be that bad. That ambiance is great. Given the quality of the food and the reputation of the place, the atmosphere is quite laid back. Definitely worth a visit.

7Ditx-NZN2R_4xrNKEUUgA.text: So, so delicious.My friend and I arrived at about 7:30 for our 8:00 reservations, but were seated right then.  I was immediately impressed by the look/feel of the place which is like, industrial meets stark meets reclaimed wood floors, meets awesome.  The hostess offered to take our coats, which is always nice, and hung them on the wall pegs that surround the restaurant.  So it's almost like your coat becomes part of the decor, which is kinda cool!Things I had:  roasted bone marrow, crispy pig cheek with dandelion, Welsh rarebit, and shared brown bread ice cream and fresh baked madeleines for dessert.  Things my friend had: brown crab on toast, whole sole, sprout tops.  Was it all delicious?  Yes.  Yes, every last bit and morsel of that meal was fantastic.  The bone marrow, as many others have testified is so perfect with that fresh parsley salad.  Really, I wouldn't have minded just a giant mound of that parsley salad because it is yum.  The crispy pig cheek?  COME ON.  At first, I thought a couple of the bits of skin were croutons!  Then I quickly realized when one "crouton" had a bit of tender, delicious pork attached that no, no indeed... that is NOT a crouton and is just amazing, delicious, crispy skin.  Perfect marriage of crispy skin and perfectly tender cheek.  And I assume there was a bit of mustard in the dandelion which helped cut the richness of the cheek.  It was perfect, and I noted that when we were ordering dessert, it was sold out.  I'd never had Welsh rarebit, but with the Worcestershire sauce provided, it was like an open-face grilled cheese of the gods.  The ice cream was so, so good and can best be described as sweet cream with grape nuts (which is a cereal in the US so this description probably only makes sense to about 50% of the people reading), and the fresh madeleines were bouncy, fluffy, and lovely.My only minor nag was that the fresh bread served at the beginning, while tasty, was served cold.  Warm that fantastic bread up, St John!  However, service was lovely, all my stupid "what is a chitterling" type questions were answered, and the waiter was cute, to boot, which never hurts.  Would definitely go back.

fP_H8ABueX03T4EqHmO0Jg.text: St John's is one of my favourite restaurant's in London. The classy white exterior is continued inside with very minimalist wooden furniture and a stainless steel bar. Somehow though, this doesn't feel at all cold or uncomfortable, it's just perfect. The menu at St John's won't suit everyone and if you are at all squeamish about odd cuts of meat or unusual ingredients then may I suggest you keep your distance. This is also not the sort of place where a bowl of chips arrives on the side of every plate as the tried and tested vegetable option. St John's tries to be as seasonal as possible, selecting the very best produce and messing about with it as little as possible. A bowl of purple sprouting broccoli arrives exactly as it sounds, maybe with a knob of butter on top if the chef is feeling especially extravagant. On my last visit my boyfriend and I shared one of the best starters I've ever had. A bowl brimming with langoustine arrived with only bread and mayonnaise as it's accompaniments. Perfect. Simple. Delicious. Only a restaurant so confident in the strength of its ingredients do you get this kind of cooking. A must try!

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

JetJxCe_kUhOBq_EKX4Vxg.text: I love the area- ironically, close to St Bart's HospitalI am a carnivore and I love offal.  I enjoyed the bone marrow & parsley salad - who knew marrow and grains of salt with parsley on toast who taste so good and yummy. I think I had the Berkshire pork for main and probably treacle tart for pudding. All very good and very reasonable.Got there early but the place filled up pretty quickly afterward. Very interesting architecture and design. I enjoyed my meal so much I went to St John Bread and Wine for an encore dinner the next day

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. bone marrow/parsley
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

l9I6xPcFHSN1Exe2gpR5HA.text: We were in London for a few days and seized the opportunity to eat/drink/ go out as much as we can. We trampled into this place just before heading out to Paris on the Eurorail. I was so glad we tried it. We were seated upstairs and by the time we got there, it was fairly early and people did not show up until much later. The place filled up pretty quickly for lunch and it got a little busy and noisy. The crowd were mostly men in business attire and we were pretty much the only ones in casual wear. Since we were on a time crunch, we decided to do a short and quick meal with just starters. We ordered the bone marrow with sea salt and the crispy pig cheeks with dandelion fronds tossed with a mustard vinaigrette. Reluctant as first, I hesitated to take my first bite of cheek but the rest was history after I did. This is the place where my fondness for pig cheeks were confirmed. Absolutely, incredibly delicious. Crispy, fatty, tender with a hint of smokiness, the meat was really good. The dandelions with the vinaigrette complimented the dish very well. Nicely executed. For dessert, we bought half a dozen Madeleines to take with us for the train ride and they were oh so good. Fluffy, buttery and tasty!I would have to say that although our time there was brief, it was a nice ending to our time in London. I would def come back.

sDwRRtG1DvZ4BCsSg0iyCQ.text: I really wanted to love this place and I will be sure to try it again next time I am in London, but for now, 3 stars.  I came here for a lunch meeting upon arriving in London.  It was a little bit of a trek from my hotel, but Anthony Bourdain said its a place to eat before you die, so I had to give it a go.  To be 100%, I went during a semi-religious fast and could not eat red meat.  Therefore, I got the crab meat on whole wheat toast and the Welch Rarebit.  I will go back and try the bone marrow though.  The crab meat was clean and good, but there was no wow factor.  The Welch Rarebit was very greasy and oily (greasier than I expected).  In the end, it didn't have the nicest feel to it and the service was just ok. If I am spending 25 quid on a meal, I would have expected a little bit better.  To be continued in one year when I head back to London.

3wfEpqj8lKLNZyUmEYgYNA.text: St. John is the 'new British food' restaurant created by Fergus Henderson who espouses a love of 'noseto-tail' simple foods expertly done.Situated in Clerkenwell, the bar wraps around, but is separated from the restaurant by a glass brick wall. The bar is done in a down-home style with the kitchen and bar open on two sides. The centre has about half a dozen rustic tables. The set up is intended to create an informal feeling, which if it weren't busy it would. I got there late and two parties were dominating the space which were dominating the space which left me and my date very little choice but to wedge in where we could, which left me feeling as though I had crashed a dinner party uninvited. The bar is well-stocked with a handful of beers on draught and others in bottles, mostly from small brewers. There was also a good range of wines. The bar food fits the rustic mood but is fairly extortionately priced. It is the kind of place which deserves another trip but when I went I found the place too cliquey to be enjoyable.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

ri-qabZZl5w_WTGx0IyvGg.text: I think I first heard of this place via Anthony Bourdain.  I stopped by, saw the book on sale called Nose to Tail written by Fergus Henderson, the owner.  I became intrigued, and later by chance I met him at Spitalfields Market after a cooking demonstration ("ox heart").  I was fortunate to speak with him, and I decided to buy the book.  I've since cooked so many dishes from it at home. I've learned to use pig trotters (pig's feet) to add flavour and body to dishes, I've brined duck legs for days, and it's not only about meat.  I even prepared Celery Salt and Boiled Eggs.  But this review is about the restaurant!!  I only mention the book because many of the dishes from it are on the restaurant menu.  I know that sounds backwards, but for me, it's great to be able to see how the master has prepared them, and enjoy eating them in the unique atmosphere of his restaurant.I'd highly recommend a meal here. It seems obvious to me that this is an important, landmark restaurant of the food scene today. You can feel the respect the chef has for the food he's served, and the respect for the animal it came from.

_hYVtepL_i_Bm_27RCnTVQ.text: It's a nice place but I had higher expectations. I guess is one of these places that if you had no expectations at all it would had been a better experience. I ordered lamb fries and lamb sweetbreads. The fries were ok, nothing special about it it anything a bit too much batter and dry. Same thing with the sweetbreads, they were ok but nothing exceptional, the chunks of bacon were too big and overpowering and there was too much liquid. Service on the other side was subpar, very slow, to much waiting time. Also our waitress had a bit of an attitude, she wasn't really paying attention to our table which added waiting time. When after waiting we asked her to come to the table she appeared annoyed. In a nutshell, OK food and subpar service for a place I had high hopes for.

ngD3UW9BZUtjJgiRZ9rTVA.text: I will eat almost anything. Bone marrow here was good, but not the best I've ever had.  But the Octopus salad both looked and tasted like vomit. I've eaten a lot of octopus cooked in a lot of different ways. This was inexcusable. Literally made my wife vomit, and I came close myself. Sent it back and was still charged for it. And bad service to boot. And my pint of bitter was mediocre. 1 star is a gift. Ox heart main was quite nice as was my wife's lentils, kale and goat curd. But come on people!

u_DFmqUNrbR_D67xfIbhsQ.text: Atmosphere - despite of it looking like a canteen, i quite like the different outlay of things - keeping it simple is a good start. Although for my liking, a more ambient lighting would be more appropriate.Food. Erm...No. We ordered mutton soup and braised squid for starters; chitterlings and snail with sausage for mains. I was so expecting to dunk crusty bread into my soup...didn't happen. Soup was lacking taste, although mutton was nice and tender. Braised squid with parsnips wasn't particularly special, it was served lukewarm, which was rather a dissappointment. Snails with sausage and chickpeas were good and had a bit of a spicy hit, which I enjoyed. Chitterlings...I had to send it back. The smell was absolutely getting to me and meat (the tiny bit I tasted covering my nose) was taste-less. I ordered haddock instead, which turned out very good and probably was the main highlight of the whole meal.Desserts. Now, this is the reason why i gave it 2 rather than 1 out of 5 stars. Portions of desserts were large enough to be satisfying, but not too large so they would look bulky and 'too much'. We had chocolate terrine and pear and sherry triffle. Yes for both. Terrine was served with an unusual armagnac ice cream, was rich and as my partner expressed it was 'Chocolate heaven'. My pear and sherry triffle was absolutely delicious, but due to vast amounts of bread eaten by me earlier I couldn't finish most of it.Service. The waiter got annoyed with me noticing that squid was lukewarm, and even more so after I send back the chitterlings. He also didn't like the fact that we went out for a cigarette in the middle of the meal, even though we left our bags at the table and didn't look like people who would run away without paying. But he didn't charge us for the fish and rest of the evening he was normal to us. Verdict. I might've said I will come back for the desserts, but no - i'll have it cheaper in any other decent restaurant where I would enjoy the food as well.

O33cHtk7IdRvgvSbbrR7Iw.text: so much hype for this place.  Its OK.  The bread is good and the vibe is modern charming.  The food is OK. Had some oysters which were fresh but not blow the socks off.  Also had a crab salad on toast. The flavor was pretty good, but the dressing was a bit overpowering and there was crab shell in the salad.  That along knocks off a star.  To top it off, the place is way overpriced and the food is not all that interesting.  I think I will try the Pho place up the street the next time  I am in the area.

MqxvH2dU4-30mFHCYtYPlg.text: This restaurant has been a foodie and chef favorite for a while and always comes highly recommended. I admit I have wanted to go for ages but always held off because it is renowned for a more meat and innards type cuisine which I like, but not always in the mood for. I fancy myself as trying different foods, but sometimes being so adventurous to try the the 'whole' animal I feared I would be disappointed. Not to mention feel like I would have no idea as to what to order. Thankfully my fears were ill founded as the menu while a bit different is really quite accessible and enjoyable. Located in the trendy and happening area of Farringdon (is there anything fabulous these days that is not coming out of this Borough?), the highly touted restaurant is not pretentious in decor or menu. There are two areas for dinning, the bar area, which is an order at the bar and sit setting, or the 'formal' restaurant which is not formal at all though functionally classic with white tablecloth tables in a simple, almost cold feeling, loft style room with the kitchen in the corner.This is not a vegetarian's restaurant for sure, or a place to take picky eaters. St. John take pride in using the 'nose to the tail' of the animal, so items such as tripe salad, one of their signature dishes, and pork cheek, can make even a full fledged meat lover question what to order. I know I wouldn't eat everything on the menu and my taste was limited to one or two items in each category. I started with the roasted artichoke which was soft, tasty and melted on the tongue. That was followed with the calf's liver, which the best way for me to describe it was like a thinner version of foie gras -which by the way, I love. So, I knew what I was in for and it went beyond my expectations. Tender and savory with roast shallots  which added and almost chutney seasoning and flavoring to the dish. Somehow I had room for dessert which was a gorgeous pavlova of meringue and strawberries. Many of the desserts were fruit based which lends a fresh pallet cleanser and lighter follow up to the heavy main meal. The wine list was impressive with a quality selection of wines by the glass which is always hard to find. Service was efficient and professional.I don't know if I would call this British cooking, but it was a sort of sophisticated farmers cooking -perhaps? It is hard to categorize, so it is something one should go into with eyes open. I don't know if I would take a mixed group there, but save it more for friends who are food buffs and want something out of the ordinary. What I do know for sure is it was one of the best meals I have had and would go back again. And again.

ISqWSL9mGBAb5BTA2Te2KQ.text: A great space with lots of industrial details, understated and easy vibe. Food is made well, simply and without a lot of fuss. Bone marrow is a must, as are the in-season vegetables.

xZkstYfMAup2Atg20AO7Rg.text: Food in London has gotten a bad reputation over the past decades.  Some say that they conquered new lands to find food that wasn't boiled.  St. John is looking to change all that by serving quintessential "English" cuisine.  I love offal like a kid loves cake so I was right at home in their Spartan dining room.    We were fortunate enough to have the bone marrow since I understand that it is not always on the menu. Bourdain has claimed that this dish would be his last meal and it did not disappoint.  The marrow was beyond decadent. The razor clams, cooked with a light olive oil, were refreshingly delicious.  Since the ox heart was on the menu, we had to order it.  It tasted beefy and quite good.  The Plaice (a mild white fish) reminded my friend of her favorite childhood dish.  The fish was cooked perfectly and delicious with the sauteed leeks.  We all shared the Eccles cake with a wedge of cheddar.  I've never wanted to try mince meat but when in Rome...  Mincemeat as it turns out is a mixture of dried fruit and nuts and quite tasty.

yx4hT5GiUR_dmTV4key0XQ.text: I  have never had a bad meal at St John.  However last night's meal was truly exceptional.Between us we ordered the following.StartersCrispy Pig skin with Dandelion - home made pork crackling tossed with salad leaves.  Delicious.Cold Roast Beef with Green Beans and pickled walnuts.  Utterly sublime - perfect pink roast beef with a salad of green beans, pickled walnuts and sliced pickled shallots.  Possibly one of the best flavour combinations I have ever experienced.MainsSea Bass with Tomatoes and Ailoli.  Perfectly cooked fish, roasted tomatoes and pungent ailoli.Saddle of rabbit with Turnips and Bacon.  Beautiful tender meat, with braised turnips and bacon lardons.SweetRaspberry meringue with cream.  What's not to like?Cheese board.WineSt John Rouge - great value at £24.Bill came to £125 including tip.  Pricey but then you could pay a lot more for cooking of this standard.Service was polite, friendly and unintrusive.  I'm not sure other reviewers ate in the same restaurant as me.  I have never had a bad experience there.

gN1suvLj0V04DeiCD7u2xQ.text: I really wanted to like this place.  It did have an interesting casual setting and the menu choices were quite unusual.  I enjoy bone marrow and skate and both were on the menu and I ordered them.  Unfortunately, the skate was my and my dining partner undoing (we think), since we both were awakened 8 hours later with urgent trips to the loo.  I wrote the restaurant to inform them, but got no response.  I know these things happen, but it did put a damper on me giving this higher ratings.

QB0uUrysDRTrbyCcftuUXQ.text: This is a wonderful gem hidden away in London's otherwise unpalatable array of poorly made food. despite having 1 michelin star, the prices were very reasonable. the bone marrow was good, although not exceptional (for example, the bone marrow at Bouchon was better, in my opinion). their menu seems to be everchanging, so any specific recommendations might not be useful. everything we tried was fantastic - well prepared from quality ingredients.

9X-A-fyCocMMQ-nFd6gw2A.text: Great service and absolutely delicious food for a very reasonable price. Add it to your "London" list !

Q5vyhCemg_7oHxrKd_pJyQ.text: The only thing i would recommend you guys is the roast bone marrow. My friend had the salt mutton and i had the arbroath smokie. For the side dish, we had the green salad and welsh rarebit. Both main course are terribly too salty. I try to complained with the waitress but the response is the dishes come in the smoky, very intense way. At last it came to 76GBP in total in the bill which is quite expensive for that awful dishes. The most important is, my friend feel sick on the taxi back home, and throw up! I wont come to this place again.

V9W8gUWjie48tmtkVSeMSw.text: Although overall a great experience, my gripes were:Paying normal food prices for bone marrow. I'm not a marrow expert but that's a bit steep for what used to be peasant food...Bread at the table / bread with a starter...erm..a bit tacky in this day and age,They were definitely one service member short imho. It took foreverrrrr to get anything.The cockles were excellent though, and the middle white was an amazing cut of pork.Try the eccles cake - it is a life changer.(sorry. I drafted this months ago on my phone :3 )

dCyS4nRRo68dcpOUO8NydQ.text: Okay there is something about eating the inners of an animal that intrigues and disgusts me all in the same moment. The menu at St John is terrifying, seriously scary and if I had to choose one word, arrogant.Who says this is traditional British food? I don't remember my mum cooking this, or eating this around friends houses. It's like they've take a menu from 1956 and are still making it today. So here is my gripe, I understand that this is a meat eaters paradise but the selection was shocking and disappointing. So if I want fish, there will only be one type, and if I want veggies, yep only one of these two. But if I want tripe, bacon or pigs stomach I have a list full. I tried it, I really did, I had tripe, bacon and peas in a clear broth thingy but really it just tasted bland and slimy. Now you can't knock the service, or the wine, or the desserts. Actually this place is only a 2 star for me, it was the desserts that saved the day. Eton's mess, cheese, proper old school puddings. My eyes were popping at the idea of these delights, and when they arrived they were every bit as awesome as I though.Maybe it's a meat thing, but this didn't tick my boxes.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

fd6VTCB-bODBYXnZLxdXMQ.text: An update to my previous review: having been impressed by their bread on my first visit, I went back the other day only to buy a couple of loaves of their home-made bread...and it was delicious! I bought the breads (a rye and a sour-dough) during my lunch break and for the rest of the afternoon I was tantalized by the wondrous smells that escaped my bag. Back at home I then prepared a proper German Brotzeit consisting of several kinds of cold cuts, cheeses and pickled red cabbage - my Mom would have been so proud of me!

IGVLZ7fTrnbH-QDQHIiwyQ.text: -I've enjoyed meals at St. John in the past characterized by good, simple food and competent service though sometimes at aggressive price points.-The most recent experience, a suckling pig feast for 16, was pretty disappointing though. The combination of only adequate food and lousy service was completely at odds with the £70-80 cost per person.-The food (whole crab and lamb tongues to start, suckling pig for main and then cheese and plum pie) was fine although presentation was even more perfunctory than usual (e.g. crabs were barely prepared, no knives/spoons were provided to serve the plum pie).-The service, however, was slow, sloppy and inattentive. Vegetarian dishes were forgotten about, no effort was made to keep the table topped up with wine and water and the staff generally seemed very disengaged.-Most frustrating we were initially told that the leftover suckling pig (several kilos worth!) would be packaged up for us to take away. A waiter later claimed that a plate had been 'smashed over it' and the kitchen couldn't release it. How this could have happened when the pork was served on two plates is unclear.-This waste of a lot of good food (for which we had paid the best part of £400) is unconscionable, especially for a restaurant that prides itself on nose to tail eating. My follow up email to St. John went unanswered.-St. John is resting on its laurels and I don't plan on returning.

we3GEf4AOhEQQQyvYVI6Ww.text: Every part of the pig is served here.  Very well prepared food in a somewhat austere, quasi butcher-shop/sanitarium interior.  Maitre' d is super professional and witty. Experimenting with different menu items here is fun and adventurous.

photos.caption: Photo of St John Bar and Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

2IQMoHDd5WD2wcdvuk7K4Q.text: For the fastidious carnivores who look for those bits and portions of the animal that most folks overlook, this place is a temple to those converts.  Herein these walls are served the portions that may repel the masses but entice the enlightened.  Bone marrow, lamb tongues, ox cheeks, venison liver, veal sweetbread.. these are the offal fares that delight the palate with both pungence and subtlety.  Game meats are intense but balanced and well-prepared.The dessert offering is also very good if you manage to save some appetite.  The crumble and custard is excellent, as is the bread pudding in the delectable butterscotch.  I like the lemon meringue the best of the lot.The best way to enjoy the fares here is to be a participant of their 'feasting' menu.  Bring your friends and bring your appetite.. because this is not a meal for weight conscious.

i6b57IkehkDauuZSg0KWoQ.text: I often go to both the outside bar area for wine and tapas style dishes as well as the proper restaurant.  Gourmet english fare with many fringe proteins - a place is for people who enjoy some culinary adventure; those who want to try various parts of the animal expertly prepared and very rich flavor.  Wine is great too!Not cheap, but worth it.

35mgbHzc-vb5WZqMezL8MQ.text: Sat in the bar area because we couldn't nab a last minute reservation for an out of town visitor. Food and service were both good. Bone marrow lived up to the hype. I'm not sure why it wouldn't though. How could fatty, beefy bits spread on bread be bad? The lamb kidneys were a little too strong for my palate, but still I enjoyed the texture of them.

pK3Jmv8o2RlVNIJYFbyUdQ.text: First, the good.  Amazing fresh-baked madelines.  Service is great, from a waitstaff that is very easy on the eyes.  Appetizers were pretty good (venison heart salad, the famous marrow and parsley), though nothing special.The bad.  The mains were an EXPERIENCE but i'm not sure they were an experience in a good way.  Memorable, certainly, and food that I'm not likely to forget in a long time.  My grouse came whole and quite rare, and was extremely difficult to cut into, as it was much tougher than cutting into a chicken or squab.  My fingers became numb as I tried to saw through the breast.  I had ordered it, because the waiter mentioned that it was the gamiest thing on the menu.  I thought, how gamey could a bird that is a close relative to the chicken possibly be?  Wow, was I wrong.  For a minute I thought maybe it had putrefied or something.  But no, it was just GAMEY with a 72-point font capital G.On to G's plate of ox liver.  I've heard that liver should be served rare, but this was basically raw & crunchy.  If it were 2 bites of raw crunchy liver, that might be palatable.  But when it's 2 giant slabs of raw liver, it ain't so fun to eat.  G eats EVERYTHING, and I was pretty afraid that it was not going to end well, as he sat there with grim determination to eat the whole plate. The ugly.  Presentation was non-existent.  Ox liver and onions was a disgusting mess of brown on brown, with brown sauce slopped onto the plate -- at least wipe the edges!  Grouse was so tough to cut that I eventually gave up trying to cut and had to use my hands to try to rip meat off.  The end result on my plate looked like something a toothless dog might have left.I almost feel like I need to go back and experience all the delicious other bits and bobs that people keep mentioning in reviews...  maybe one day.

GGOG6RPgg7opzjHK0vVVdg.text: I really wanted to love St John like most people already have but i don't know if it was an off night or what, but my experience was not the innovative palette pleaser I was expecting.Usually, I can't go wrong when I'm going off of Tony Bourdain. He was grunting in satisfaction so many times on the London/Edinburgh episode while at St John that I was glad his show is on Cable TV. Therefore, I had St John high on the list of places I wanted to try while in London and was so eager to try it, that when we mistakenly stumbled into the Bread & Wine version of the restaurant, we almost had our lunch right then and there. However, our reservation was at night (late night at that) and from the get-go things were not unpleasant but definitely not up to the standards I had come to expect from a formerly Michelin rated venue.Service was adequate but yet dreadfully slow it seemed for our table of two. Having to flag down the wait staff and then wait half hour intervals was not at all my definition of a great restaurant. I think the waiting contributed to the fact that our appettites slowly deteriorated. Appetizers:Bone Marrow with Parsley - Everyone raves about this and it was fatty and very tasty. The best part of the meal by far. Brown Crab Meat on Toast - Not much to see here. Pretty standard and the crab meat wasn't exceptional nor did the flavor stand out.Vegetable Soup - Actually quite good. It was savory and even a tinge of sweet and the texture of the soup and flavors from the mixture of vegetables worked in harmony. The temperature of the dish could have been warmer though.Mains: Beef Roast - This came out lukewarm and unfortunately was way too bland. Not a good sign when the mashed potatoes are the best part of this dish.Overall, I'd say St John was a disappointment but I came in with lofty expectations and I certainly could have been more adventurous in my orders. However, service was still painfully slow and the food I did order should have been prepared better.

IwGmxrxVjltPLT6FxIDxBA.text: My parents came to visit me in London for my 35th birthday (which happened to fall inbetween the Easter and Royal Wedding bank holidays), and I decided they should take me to a new and interesting restaurant.  St. John it is.  It also helped that it's in Restaurant magazine's top 50 restaurants in the world and that it's reasonably priced.So my partner and I get there at 7:00 for 7:30 reservations.  It's in a funny place, it's basically like a giant warehouse.  It was a bit unexpected, but also added to the charm of the place.  We walked through the bar to the dining room, checked in, and decided to get a drink while we waited for my parents.  So what do you drink when you're out to celebrate?  A bit of champers!  We actually just got the house champagne, which was very reasonably priced and surprisingly tasty.  Once my parents showed up, we sat down for dinner.  The dining room is a bit plain, but again, it really adds to the charm of the place.  We got some suggestions for wine (which were all terrific and unusual).  The bread was delicious.  Looking at the menu, it was definitely my kind of food.  I love offal, and I was excited by quite a few things on the menu.  I know that the bone marrow was supposed to be amazing, but I also knew it was on the menu often, and there was a rabbit offal starter I was wanting to try, so I got that instead.  My partner and my mother got the bone marrow, and my dad got the beetroot salad.  They were all very tasty, but I think mine was the least tasty of the three.  The bone marrow was very decadent and super tasty, so when I go back, that will probably be what I get.For mains my partner and I both got sweetbreads.  My mother had rabbit and my dad had pigeon.  The sweetbreads were nice, but they weren't as good as some I've had at other places.  So slightly disappointing but good.  I had a bite of the rabbit and the pigeon and they were much better than the sweetbreads.  Next time, I'm going to try the ox heart if it's available.The desserts is where they shine.  I ordered the ginger loaf and my partner ordered the chocolate slice (and we split them), my mother had the Eton mess and my dad had the honeycomb ice cream.  They were all tasty.  I honestly couldn't decided if I preferred the ginger loaf or the chocolate.  They were both awesome.One downfall is they did forget our Madeleine order.  I did want to wait for them, but my dad was ready to go.  Apparently she was more focused on writing down which one got a candle.  She did feel bad.So not perfect food or perfect service, but it was definitely up there.  But the price is quite reasonable, so it feels like a place you can go back to more often than just once.  I definitely want to go back and try some other things on the menu.  I also want to try to get enough people together to get a roast pig.  So why five stars?  Because they don't have a 4.5 option.  I really keep waffling between 4 and 5.  It wasn't perfect, but I had such a great time.

8iOaqH889bFCypLJKcgD0w.text: It lived up to its hype as one of the best restaurants in London.  I went in expecting a hearty, offal-driven meal and St John delivered  big time.We started off with the iconic bone marrow.  I've had bone marrow many times, and honestly, I feel like it's either done well or it's not, not much in between.  St John's version was not only perfectly prepared, but the pairing with the super fresh parsley added another dimension I'd never experienced with marrow before.  The parsley (and a sprinkle of sea salt) married incredibly well with the rich and savory marrow.  It had me wondering why I'd never seen this simple pairing before, truly inspired.  It actually stood out in the world of roasted marrow bones, bravo.From there we ordered with trotter and pheasant pie (for two) but it could have fed four.  The crust was thick and flaky with lots of animal fat flavor and an impressive crunch.  The trotters were tender and lent a richness to the leaner, but moist pheasant.  The pie was a short course on how to properly prepare a rich dish so it's enjoyable rather than heavy.The perfect dessert was the recommendation from the waitress for a kick ass cocktail bar down the street (Zetter Townhouse).

dgxbJCCeapXltqwbMHwCNg.text: Ranked 41st in the 2011 edition of S. Pellegrino's World's 50 Best Restaurants List, St. John is a London restaurant specializing in game and offal dishes prepared in a no-fuss manner and environment. With a rotating menu that features dishes such as Chitterlings and Radishes, Pigeon and Carrots, and Deviled Lamb Kidneys on Toast, the menu is not for the unadventurous or faint-of-heart, but it's just the place if you are looking for simple, well-executed meat and game. As an Anthony Bourdain-approved restaurant, St. John was high up on my list of potential restaurants to dine at while in London, and I managed to snag a 10:00 pm seating for Saturday night. Unfortunately, the late hour meant that some of the menu items were already sold out, but luckily, the much-acclaimed Roast Bone Marrow and Parsley Salad was still available. As this was my first time eating bone marrow, I was not quite sure what to expect. Let me first say that procuring bone marrow from the bones is a ridiculously messy process, and it really does get quite oily. Maybe that's just because I'm a novice at the art of extracting fatty, jelly-like substances from bones, though. Anyway, my hands were sufficiently coated in a thick layer of fat and grease by the time I finished the dish. The bone marrow, which is the consistency of jelly or congealed animal fat, is actually fairly mild in flavor, and it leaves a thick coating of grease all over your lips (and hands) when you've finished eating. Essentially, bone marrow is like mildly-flavored meat fat, so I can't say I was wowed by the flavors of the dish. The rock salt was key in adding some flavor, but I thought that the parsley salad was way too overpowering to complement the bone marrow, so I just ate it between bites of bone marrow to help cut through some of the richness and heaviness of the fat.With the menu that night seeming to be a bit tame with the offal dishes, I went with the Braised Rabbit, Bacon, and White Beans. Definitely not the most adventurous of dishes, the dish was comprised of extremely tender rabbit meat that literally fell right off of the bone. Mixed in with some chunks of bacon and beans in a stew-like dish, it was a hearty and tasty bowl of food, though I'm a bit disappointed that I didn't get a chance to try something like Ox Hearts, which were on the menu the previous night.For dessert, the baked-to-order Madelines were very tempting, but I couldn't see myself finishing a half-dozen of them, so I opted for Harry Potter's favorite dessert - Treacle Tart. Despite being described by the waitress as "very sweet syrup poured into a pastry crust," I was a bit unprepared for just how sweet the tart really was. Although I've never had pecan pie, I'm guessing that Treacle Tart is very similar but just without the pecans to cut through the sweetness. There were hints of fruitiness as well, but the syrupy tart filling is hyperglycemia-inducingly sweet. The crust lacked the flakiness that I prefer from pastry crusts, but it had a nice, almost-burnt taste that I am personally a fan of. An okay dessert, but not something that I'd order again.In summary, my meal at St. John was fine, but I think I probably ordered the wrong dishes and didn't get the dishes that would have left me with the best impression and representation of St. John's cuisine. I'm a bit disappointed, but that's more due to the fact that I had such great expectations coming into the meal. Was it the 41st-best restaurant in the world? I think that's impossible for me to affirm or disagree with, especially after only dining there once. It's safe to say, though, that the food is well-executed and the menu features plenty of interesting choices. How long the fad of head-to-tail eating lasts is anyone's guess, but I'm pretty sure it's safe to say that St. John will stick around long after the trend dissipates.

Jyph0B1oR1HxLcN4plc02g.text: Before I gave birth, me and my husband would often come to St. John's. Right now we're tied up with the baby but still love the tasty food and the pints of beer. I'm basically not a seafood person, but each time I'm here become a one.Can't wait to visit it again.

UoZSliMWt3MguxubiRxy0g.text: Went for lunch. Has a cooling setting and is tucked away between two buildings. The food was delicious (and the bread, of course)- everything was very fresh. Had the salt kid, bone marrow, squid, artichoke (yum!).

3KozHdd1sDryyS4GeTiwGA.text: I have never and may never have a meal quite like the one I had at St. John. Everything about it seemed just... different. From the perspective of food - I had a great many tastes that were new and delicious: be that bone marrow, hearts, or an incredible date and toffee sauce. From the perspective of service: It was entirely unstuffy, but at the same time, we felt that our waiter could anticipate exactly what we wanted from our meal. I had never had a Tasting Menu with Ale before - but it came out perfectly here. In a restaurant defined (in some ways) by pork, we enjoyed a multi-course meal that was entirely pig free.St. John is a Michelin Starred restaurant, but also a working pub - with tables and stools for those to drop by an enjoy a beer or two. After wandering into the Dining Room, our meal contained one great surprise after another. Fresh Sea Urchins, Bone Marrow and Parsley Salad, Smoked Fish, Creamy Haddock with Saffron, Country Fowl with Sweet Potatoes, Madeleines, Toffee and Date Cake, Eccles Cake - everything tasted delicious. Some were rich. Well, most were rich. But the contrast amongst tastes and textures was stark. And all the while we were treating incredibly by servers who clearly care deeply about their food and their restaurant. The highlight? Probably the desserts. Make sure to save room.In a word - St. John was awesome. I will be back.

_Bpw1AMOYKNdcW2x0WUsHA.text: I've been a fan of Fergus Henderson's nose to tail eating for years, long enough to see it go mainstream and see bone marrow and pigs trotters served at many other places now.Some misconceptions about the restaurant:* Yes, it's all about the meat so it may be difficult for a vegetarian but there's usually a fish dish on the menu every night.* Although it does strive to serve up offal, not all the dishes will be offal.  There is normal food there.* It's not like this weird restaurant where you go to test the extreme foods you will eat.  It's just a normal nice restaurant where some of the dishes are made from offal.* Although the chef is quite famous now, this restaurant feels more like your local nice restaurant.  It's not hoity toity or fancy.  You do not need to dress up in a suit to eat here.Bike Parking: on the island across the street from the restaurant.
